Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week Four
Content:
Hello dear readers, and welcome to the first edition of my confinement cooking newsletter.

Based on the subscribers list as I compose this, my first letter is going to have a pretty limited audience. I'm not trying to turn myself into a food celebrity. But I'd love to know if you're enjoying this, and I'd strongly encourage you to plug this to all your friends. I'm not above admitting that having an audience helps keep me motivated. Not that I have all that much else to do with my time.

For now, this isn't meant to be trendy meal plan-style set of recommendations with a shopping list. If you're looking for me to lay out a plan for your life, there are tons of people doing that elsewhere. I'm hoping a slightly looser approach can still be interesting.

For the past few weeks I've been doing soups for lunch. They're easy to make in advance, and I appreciate the minimal cognitive requirements of mindless reheating. This week, I'm doing something new and something true.

On the experimental side, I'm trying out this recipe for a curried lentil and coconut soup from the always wonderful Yotam Ottolenghi. Miraculously I was able to find dried black beans on my latest supply run, so I'm alternating with a basic black bean soup. Both can be made vegetarian, possibly even vegan. I'm not devout enough for that. I made chicken stock with leftovers a couple of weeks ago, and plan to savor every drop.

These soups would not be complete without some bread, which I'm continuing to make with my own sourdough starter. It also makes great toast with butter and jam for breakfast.

For dinner, I'm planning to try out a recipe for Chinese-style steamed buns (bao) from Taku Sekine, who made his reputation at Dersou in Paris. I've tried making bao before, and have yet to succeed. Perhaps confinement cooking will save me.

After an unintentionally Italian week last week, I thought I'd do something French. I had it in my head to make salmon with a warm lentil salad. Except that my local Whole Foods was out of green lentils. So instead, I'm going a little further south and planning to do salmon with a shaved fennel salad.

And to use up the dregs of a couple of bottles of white wine, I bought some frozen shellfish — a secret weapon, confinement or not — and plan to toss together a seafood risotto.

Eating at home is no reason not to have some sweet treats as well. I still have some leftover hot cross buns from Good Friday. Once those are exhausted, I'm thinking of making the rye cocoa cake from the new Poilâne cookbook. It sounds like a slightly ludicrous flavor pairing, but something about the slight sour tang of the rye flour really goes well with the mellow darkness of the chocolate.

Cooking only for myself, I'll probably alternate these dishes according to my mood. If you're looking for another meal idea, I love Tom Kerridge's recipe for lemon pepper chicken with potatoes.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week Five
Content:
Welcome to another week of confinement cooking.

It's very exciting: this fun newsletter has crossed into a double-digit number of subscribers! I'll keep going regardless, but I'd still encourage you to tell your friends to sign up too.

Before we consider my plan for the week ahead, a bit of reflection on the week before.

Most of what I made was familiar repertoire. I can make risotto in my sleep. There was one notable challenge: the bao. How difficult could it be? Pretty difficult. Not to the point that I failed completely. But there's a lot to learn. It reminds me of trying to bake bread. Superficially, it's so simple, but doing it well depends so much on mastering so many tiny details.

My other experiment — the Ottolenghi red lentil-coconut soup — was more of a success. It would have looked better with a verdant hit of cilantro. Alas, I forgot to buy it when I did my weekly shop. I'm also too much of a wimp for quantity of red pepper flakes he suggests. The piquancy aside, it's definitely a recipe that's going to enter my repertoire.

Moving to the week ahead, I'm trying to at least eat like it's spring, even if I'm not entirely sure how to execute that in the kitchen, and I can't meaningfully go outside and enjoy the spring weather.

After over a month eating nothing but soup for lunch, I've decided it's time for a change. Something about fennel feels vernal. Perhaps the color. In any case, that led me to thinking I'd make a fennel quiche. It's easy enough to make, and it reheats nicely. Despite appearances, my dedication does not extend with making a quiche from scratch every day for lunch.

As much as I love the freedom to cook more and more elaborately, I'm also ready for a bit of a break. One of my go-to speedy suppers is a black bean burger with rosemary-thyme oven-roasted purple sweet potato wedges. I linked to an excellent recipe from Felicity Cloake. I like to make mine more interesting with some miso and Chinese five spice. It's obviously not necessary to use purple sweet potatoes. They're fun, though, if you can find them.

I'm also hoping that I can get some nice fish to do a fish stew. It's maybe not quite in season, but it snowed over this weekend, and I'm in the mood for something warming and comforting. This will go with some nice polenta and in-season asparagus. Fingers crossed my local Whole Foods has the good stuff in stock. Assuming they have fresh asparagus, I'll probably chargrill the asparagus under the broiler, maybe finished with a vinaigrette.

This plus leftovers from last week will likely tide me over for the week ahead. I am very tempted to buy some skirt steak and make steak with chimichurri sauce. That would go very nicely with oven-roasted new potatoes and more of that in-season asparagus. If you're looking for a vegetarian option, I love this barbecue eggplant preparation from the lovely people at Honey and Co in London.

For something sweet and a little more experimental, I'm going to continue feeding my rye-chocolate obsession. There's a recipe for rye double-chocolate cookies Joanne Chang's latest cookbook, Pastry Love, that I'm planning to give a try.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week Six
Content:
Hello once again dear readers,

When I threw together this idea a couple of weeks ago, more than one person told me that the name was too fatalistic. Then I discovered that the Financial Times has a new feature called "Bunker Food." If that's not fatalistic, I don't know what is. So I shall take solace knowing I share a fatalistic sense of humor with the editors of the FT. It's good company to keep.

One of my classic recipes threw me for a loop. Due to the ongoing flour shortage, I decided to make the shortcrust pastry for my fennel tart with my somewhat less depleted stock of white whole wheat flour. That was a mistake. The dough had no elasticity and fell apart as I was trying to roll it out. As was buying one of the last pieces of Gruyère cheese at my local Whole Foods. It was strangely bland. Needless to say, the fennel tart did not meet its usual standard.

I also failed to read the recipe for the rye double-chocolate cookies well enough, so I'll have to give that recipe another shot in the week ahead. I did not buy enough chocolate, and didn't realize that I was completely out of walnuts.

After a week with minimal experimentation, I've decided to take another stab at making croissants. My most recent attempt last Christmas set the oven on fire and required the use of a fire extinguisher. I'm hoping to do more than a little better than that. The secret, apparently, is using butter with a very high fat content.

For the week ahead, I've decided to go a little offbeat and do a vegetarian cottage pie to last me through the week for lunch. I may have had to buy more red lentils than I was expecting to a couple of weeks ago when I made the red lentil and coconut soup.

As it's going to be a rainy week and I haven't really eaten any pasta for a month, I thought I'd go back to an old favorite and do my quick ragù alla bolognese with rigatoni. I feel like I'm not truly participating in our collective confinement without eating some pasta. It also reheats nicely and might make a nice lunch one or two days during the week. At dinner, I like to precede that with a sharp arugula and parmesan salad, which is nothing more than baby arugula tossed with shaved parmesan cheese and a quick vinaigrette.

I've been seduced again by Taku Sekine's Instagram account, and have a yen to make scallion pancakes.

I feel slightly sacrilegious about it, but I'm planning to pair that with lemongrass chicken, jasmine rice, and pan-seared tenderstem broccoli with honey, garlic, and red pepper flakes. I'd also highly recommend Charles Phan's cookbook, Vietnamese Home Cooking. His restaurant, The Slanted Door, in San Francisco, is a favorite.

If you're looking for something else, this week I'll suggest doing a simple roast chicken. I'm a big fan of the Thomas Keller recipe, roasting the chicken on a bed of root vegetables. I'd also highly recommend using the chicken remains to make a simple chicken stock. As I mentioned in one of the earlier missives, chicken stock made with an actual chicken is so much better than the stuff in a box or a can, it's almost hard to believe. And it's so easy: take the chicken remains (read: carcass), toss it in a giant pot with some chunks of carrot, celery, and maybe some thyme and peppercorns, cover it with water and let it gently simmer for a few hours. Then strain, and you can even freeze it for making soup or risotto a month from now.

As ever, if you're enjoying this — or not — I'd love to know, and I'd once again encourage you to share this with your friends if you're enjoying it. It's a slightly steeper hill to climb to get this into triple figures, but given how long this confinement may last, I figure it's worth a try.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week Seven
Content:
Hello once again fellow confined readers,

The last week has been mostly successful. Once again, I still haven't quite found a place to try making the rye double-chocolate cookies. My closest attempt was the evening I almost made them, but decided I wanted something lighter and threw together a blueberry crumble. I did rouse myself to trying scallion pancakes for the first time. They were very tasty — the simple soy-vinegar sauce makes all the difference — even if I couldn't quite get them as light and fluffy as I had hoped the would be.

I'm now realizing that I repeat certain dishes more often than I thought. This is in some ways a good exercise to make me bring some old favorites back into my rotation. Though I have to also admit there are some things I have trouble motivating myself to prepare when it's only me. The other day the idea of a nice lasagne came into my head, and it seemed like too much bother.

Speaking of repeats, I've decided that now is the time to try doing bao again. They're a little too light as a standalone dinner, as I discovered on my first attempt, but I think they could work well as the better part of a lunch. The plan is to make a batch, stash them in the refrigerator, and then revivify them in the steamer during the week. Once I got a handle on the pleating technique, it all fell into place.

For something a little more classic, I'm going to do a miso salmon donburi, though I'm out of furikake and I have my doubts about the vaguely Asian section of my local Whole Foods. I've been so disappointed by the dried soba noodles they sell I'm going to try making my own soba noodles from scratch to do a cold soba noodle and vegetable salad.

My favorite baking YouTube channel has me in the mood to do a fougasse. And fougasse means I have to do something redolent of the south of France. Between the late spring and pandemic, I'm not convinced I can get good enough produce to make a convincing salad niçoise, and it's definitely too early in the season to do my take on a ratatouille. So instead I'm going to deplete my supply of frozen fish and try improvising something with cod, fennel, and haricots verts. I suspect a large quantity of olive oil and maybe some thyme will be involved.

In the same spirit, for another idea, I also considered doing a pan bagnat, another classic from the Nice region. It's actually pretty simple, and by far the best way to used tinned tuna as a sandwich. Though if you're going to make a pan bagnat, it's probably worth getting good tinned tuna rather than the dull generic stuff. For something vegetarian, I almost decided to do Felicity Cloake's vegetarian chili recipe this week.

For something sweet, I'm going to make my third attempt at mustering the energy to do the rye double-chocolate cookies. In the spirit of creating somewhat original content, last weekend was Anzac Day, and, solemnness aside, it's a good excuse to make some Anzac biscuits.

As ever, I'd love feedback, and if you're enjoying this, drop a line to your friends!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week Eight
Content:
Hello fellow cooks,

The last week has been a mix of success and failure. Rather than make croissants, I gave some friends a lesson in making baguettes. They all did me proud. That bread wound up replacing the fougasse that I was planning to make. One can only eat so much. I'm going to have to find another excuse to giving fougasse a try after my last somewhat disastrous attempt probably a decade ago.

My first attempt at soba was more of an unmitigated disaster. I didn't have the right kind of buckwheat flour, and the noodles really did not work. They were borderline inedible, and certainly didn't make for an especially nice noodle salad. Apparently they're very finicky. I've found another recipe from a fancy artisanal mill that makes me think this is going to be even finickier than French bread. Depending on my mood, I may put in an order for some of their buckwheat flour and see if my second attempt is any more successful.

My second pass at bao did make for a nice lunch. They still don't look quite as good as the ones in glossy food photos, but they've passed the  Adding dried porcini failed to turn my improvised vegetarian barbecue mushroom filling into something truly delicious. I don't want to give up on finding a good formulation for a veggie filling, but there may come a point I decide these are more of a treat and use pork.

For the week ahead, I'm going to do another roast chicken, assuming I can get my hands on a bird. That should take care of dinner one evening, maybe two, and, more importantly gives me another chance to use the leftovers for other interesting ideas. In particular, I'm thinking of doing a curried chicken salad tartine with more dark crusty bread. I like to swap yogurt for the mayonnaise for food preservation reasons more than anything. If you're going to use mayonnaise, you have to make it yourself, and you have to use raw egg yolks. It's not a combination that keeps especially well.

The chicken salad likely won't last the week, so I'm thinking of also using this as a chance to refine my technique for the scallion pancakes I tried recently. I'll probably pair that with something that doesn't require a ton of cleanup like a fennel or arugula salad.

Asparagus season appears to have come and gone without my local Whole Foods getting the good stuff. Perhaps I need to make a trip to Eataly. Something about that feels like a violation of the spirit of our current confinement. Even going for provisions once a week feels like it might be too often. I'm still keeping my eyes peeled in any case. And if they have it, I'm in the mood for something classic like this preparation with a mustard sauce and a poached egg.

In addition to the chicken, I'm going to do a mushroom tartelette. I'm on the fence about using puff or shortcrust pastry. The shortcrust pastry feels better to me. I have a very strong association between mushrooms and puff pastry vol-au-vent served at fancy parties. Something about that makes me want spinach. I could do something in step with that (like spinach quickly wilted with garlic in a very hot pan), but I'm probably going to go rogue and do something closer to a saag paneer.

Apropos of nothing, my favorite baking YouTube channel had a video on making crackers with leftover levain. It's not really possible to have drinks parties for obvious reasons, and there's something about being on a video conference call that makes other people eating very strange, but I still think it's worth experimenting with.

For something sweet, I'm going to finally try the rye double-chocolate cookie recipe. Yes, really. I'll post a photo on Instagram. If you've already tried the double-chocolate cookie recipe because I've now mentioned it three weeks in a row, I still think it's too early to switch fully into summer dessert mode. I'm going to suggest doubling down on chocolate and trying this recipe for milk chocolate and condensed milk cupcakes from the folks at Honey and Co.

If you're enjoying this, I'd once again encourage you to share this with your friends. I'd also love to know if you're trying anything new, or have any ideas for what I should cook next.

Stay sane,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week Nine
Content:
Hello yet again dear readers,

Finally, for real, I made a batch of the much-mentioned double-chocolate rye cookies from Joanne Chang's latest cookbook, Pastry Love. I'm tempted to tinker with them the next time I make them. The rye didn't come through the many (and, let it be said, wonderful) layers of chocolate.Nothing else was tremendously remarkable. It's been forever since I've done a curried chicken salad, and it's still as good a concept as ever. Scallion pancakes are one of my new favorite things. Though perhaps that's not so surprising given they're bread with some scallions baked in. I also walked some folks through making scones. Mine were a little homely looking due to inattention, but otherwise quite nice.
I've decided to make pasta my big project for the week ahead. For a few months when I was a teenager I borrowed a pasta machine and made a lot of it, and I hadn't tried making fresh pasta again until fairly recently. That attempt convinced me I had lost my touch. But I also have a moratorium on buying any new kitchen equipment until I've finished renovating my kitchen — who know when that will be — which means no pasta machine. I'm going to take a risk — and risk wasting some precious flour — and try doing fresh pasta by hand.

Sometimes I can't quite summon the energy to cook, and last weekend I bought some frozen butternut squash ravioli from the freezer case in lieu of making lunch. They weren't that bad, but they also weren't the best thing I've ever eaten. The filling was a little too sweet, and the pasta was a little too thick and gummy. That seems like a good enough place to start to me. It's been at least a decade since I've made stuffed pasta from scratch, so it should be an adventure. The thought is to make a big batch of squash ravioli, and have those for lunch.

After making two giant batches of chicken stock in the last two months, I need to make something that will use at least some of it up. I could obviously make soup, though after having soup for lunch the better part of six weeks, I'm inclined to do something a little different. I considered doing a chicken braise. The weather is feeling more springlike, and that feels too heavy. I'm going to be a little bit boring and do a paella. It's really not that hard to make at home. I usually wind up using arborio rice, which is pretty easy to find. In more normal times I might hunt down Spanish bomba rice, and even then I'm not entirely convinced it's that much better.

My local fish counter has been more poorly stocked than usual. I'd really like to try recreating a simpler variation on a monkfish dish I had at a very swanky restaurant on vacation last winter. There's no way I'm making a foie gras sauce at home, but I would like to steal their idea of cutting the fish into sections, rather than cooking a piece whole. Keeping with its inspiration without going quite as far, I'll probably make a beurre blanc. This might also be a good way to slot in my fougasse scheme from a couple of weeks ago.
With the weather turning and the prospect of travel to Normandy down to zero, I've thrown together some moules marinère. It's an amazingly simple dish and very redolent of warmer weather. My usual preference would be to mop up the wonderful sauce with bread, though I'll admit I bought some frozen shoestring potatoes for a bit of variety. I can't be bothered to deep fry at home.
Most mornings I have a pretty boring breakfast. I'm honestly not big on breakfast food, so it's usually steel cut oats or a slice of toast with butter and jam. This week I decided to mix things up a little and do overnight oats.

For something sweet, my current thinking is tossing together a raspberry polenta cake. I use the wonderful River Cafe recipe for the cake and toss in some raspberries. The original 1995 River Cafe Cookbook with its blue cover is perhaps my favorite cookbook. Or at least the one I crack open the most often. It can be a bit hard to find in the United States, but it's worth trying to hunt down a copy.

Have you enjoyed the addition of my mediocre food photography? As ever, I'd love your feedback and for you to share this with folks if you're enjoying it.

Stay hungry,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 10
Content:
Hello again hungry readers,

When I began doing this, I think I had an inkling that it would last more than a couple of weeks. It's still surreal that this is the tenth week with no restaurants and a mandate not to make more than one trip for food a week.

In the end, I was not able to get my hands on monkfish last week. So instead I bought some outrageously overpriced (though admittedly very tasty) halibut, which I also cooked in small pieces, and served with a beurre blanc. The hit of vinegar with the sweetness of the wine and richness from the butter and cream is fantastic.
The hand-rolled pasta was actually fairly successful from a how-good-does-this-taste perspective. The filling could've been a touch sweeter — maybe a hint of honey next time; I couldn't get my hands on amaretto biscuits — but it was otherwise very nice. It was less successful from an effort-versus-flavor perspective. The pasta machine really is helpful for rolling it out. If this confinement lasts much longer, I may have to make an exception to my moratorium on new kitchen equipment.

For the week ahead, I discovered that the local Eataly is open for business, less the restaurants. This is exciting because it means I can get really good canned tomatoes again. I'm a fan of the Afeltra product, which is also available to order online if you're not near an Eataly. Their dried pasta is also superb, if a little pricey. Something about the tomato availability (and perhaps their excellent value fresh mozzarella) put me in the mood to do pizza at home again. It would be nice if I could have it outside in the summer sun at my favorite pizza place, but that, alas, looks unlikely to be possible.

I use Ken Forkish's Neapolitan-style pizza dough recipe. His pizza place in Portland is a favorite. I'm also a huge advocate of the baking steel, made here in Massachusetts, apparently. It makes a big difference, and it's great for baking bread as well. At home I always go for the basic margherita with tomato sauce, cheese, and fresh basil. My one nod to heterodoxy is the addition of thyme, likely the product of the summer I spent in the Languedoc.

Both Ken's and Marta, Danny Meyer's great pizza place in New York, do roasted vegetable platters along with the pizza, cooked (I assume) in the same fancy super hot ovens. My lack of a wood-burning brick oven notwithstanding, I feel a lot less guilty blasting the oven for dinner if I can also take care of the greens portion of the meal.

Keeping with the posh takeout theme, something has put me in the mood for tacos as well. I don't know that I follow a recipe, exactly. Usually I do something like yoghurt-marinated chicken or marinated fish, throw together a few accouterments like quick pickle onions and a simple salsa, add some cilantro and crema, and do a bit of DIY at the table with good store-bought corn tortillas.

Finally, I'm going to put my newfound pasta-making skills to use and toss together a simple pasta with a salad of some sort. Cutting strips is a lot easier than making a filling and delicately joining two sheets of pasta. My desperation for asparagus may push me over the edge and get me to buy the slightly suspicious stalks imported from California, likely grown year round. It's never the same as the really good in-seasons stuff, but I have to have my fix. As a salad, I love serving it just-cooked sort of lukewarm with an anchovy dressing. For the pasta, maybe a green bean and tomato tagliatelle.

While I would hardly call the response to the pandemic adequate, it's getting better, and businesses have begun tentatively reopening. Partly out of laziness, partly out of a desire for novelty, and partly out of a genuine desire to keep these folks in business, I'm planning to go out and buy my lunches next week. It's a great excuse to get out of the house in the afternoon. It's great to be able to support places like Flour.

A few weeks ago I had planned to give making croissants another try. I can't remember what displaced that, but suffice to say I didn't do it. This week, I'm doing another bake-along with friends. I fear their confidence in me is misplaced, but we'll give it a try. For anyone who's been disappointed that I link so often to my favorite YouTube channel in French, they've subtitled the croissant videos in English.

That may not be enough in the sweet department, however. The weather here has also turned, which means we're back in fruit dessert territory. In all likelihood, I'll toss together some kind of fruit tart. What exactly, I'll probably decide when I see what my local Whole Foods has on offer. There's some artistry involved, but it will almost certainly have a pâte sucrée base. One of my goals in life is to replicate the amazing white peach tart I had at a nondescript restaurant I happened upon one summer in the south of France. Perhaps in an August edition of the newsletter.
As ever, I'd love feedback. Have any suggestions been particular inspiring? Is there something I should cook? And please evangelize: if you're enjoying the newsletter, tell your friends!

Stay sane and keep cooking,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 11
Content:
Hello again fellow food enthusiasts,

It's been another week of ups and downs in the food department.

On the plus side, having the folks at Flour back in my life has been great. While tossing together lunch (by which I mean reheating something I've made earlier) is hardly a burden, it's nice to have someone else cook for me, and also great to have an excuse to leave the house and go for a walk in the middle of the day.
My cook-along with friends last weekend was also a success. I still haven't quite mastered the croissant, but I made progress. I had a lot less butter leakage than the previous batches I've made, and the lamination was excellent. It's also gratifying to see a bunch of lovely people — none of whom had ever made croissants before! — give it a great first attempt. I think we all came away with something that at least tasted great. The pizza was also pretty good. I'm a little more practiced at that. I was also reminded how much better the good tinned tomatoes are than the ersatz San Marzano tomatoes at Whole Foods.
I tried Caviar for the first time, and was not bowled over. I used it to place a pickup order at one of my favorite fashionable bowl places (think Sweetgreen, except it wasn't Sweetgreen in the case), and they forgot to include my fish. The recourse? Apparently I was supposed to violate all the public health guidance and inspect the bowl before leaving.

For the week ahead, I'm going to resume my make-at-home lunches. Wonderful as Flour, Sweetgreen, and my other favorite lunch spots are, I need a little more variety in my life. I've given up on making my own stuffed pasta without a pasta machine, so I'll pick up some prepared ravioli of some sort. Don't judge. I'm also planning to throw together a batch of black bean soup. It's a favorite, and it's been at least a month since I've done that for lunch.

I half joke that I like to have a steak a couple of times a year, and I think this week may be one of my steak weeks. There's a part of me that wants to go all-out and do a ribeye steak with an incredibly rich mustard-cognac-butter sauce. Then I remember that it's effectively summer, and that's a bit too heavy. Instead, I'm planing to do a skirt steak cooked sous vide in a water bath, then seared, and served with a chimichurri, crusty bread, and a light salad. Never in my life have I been buying this much flour or this much parsley.

Because I'm boring and bored, I'm going to resurrect something I haven't made in at least a decade: the Ina Garten ginger chicken. My frugality and sense of civic duty are too strong to let me do it, but I do muse about renting a house in Amagansett to escape the monotony of my admittedly rather cushy urban confinement. For what I could afford, I doubt the kitchen facilities would be a lot better. I doubt too the farmer's markets are going to be quite as vibrant as usual this summer with safe distancing in place. Though being close to the beach and away from traffic would be nice. Her store on Long Island shut down years ago now from what I understand. Somehow my brain made the connection.

As penance for my bovine sins, I'm also going to do a vegetarian dinner. My default for veggie dinner is usually something with mushrooms, which I like, but I'm always in search of variety. So instead, I'm going to do a dal with red lentils, with other veggies, and — assuming I can get my hands on a resupply — basmati rice.
For something sweet, I'm very tempted to make another run at croissants. Or if not that, perhaps I'll pick up some extra apples, and try to recreate one of my real favorites: the Poilâne tarte aux pommes. I've made the link between the folding technique for those and the bao, and I think I'm ready for another attempt. Though I may not make my own puff pastry.
Oh, and one more glamour shot of the croissants to keep you interested. Largely because styling fish tacos without them getting cold was not going to happen. (Flavor and my eating pleasure come first.) As ever, I'd love to hear your confinement cooking stories, and if you're enjoying this, please tell your friends! It was pretty easy to break into the tens of subscribers, but 100 is a steeper climb.

Stay hungry,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 12
Content:
Hello once again dear readers,

Another week, another raft of meals behind me and to come.

Everything went more or less according to plan. The black bean soup was as good as ever. The red lentil dal was a wonderful spicy kick in this hot weather.

Forcing myself to haul out my immersion circulator was a great excuse to play around with low-temperature cooking. Steak with chimicurri is pretty difficult to mess up, especially when it's cooked in a water bath. I did put together the fact that chimicurri is very similar to an Italian salsa verde. Not that there's anything wrong with that. More interesting was the Ina Garten recipe, which I wound up cooking sous vide rather than in a roasting pan in the oven. I managed to track down a copy of the Barefoot Contessa TV episode featuring the dish, and realized she uses a far coarser grater than I would typically pull out for the ginger. The bigger bits of ginger were really nice. I loved the intense bursts of gingery fire as opposed to the mellower kick of something more finely grated. That said, I remain dubious that there's anything Indonesian about the recipe.
In the end I did not make my own puff pastry (or even buy it) to do the tartes aux pommes. Instead I gave myself a bit of a breakfast treat and did more whole wheat currant scones. I also ran out of my usual morning black tea. Fortunately the scones didn't clash too much with the green tea I've switched to. It will take some time to restock: I buy the majority of my tea — and all my breakfast black tea — from the excellent folks at Postcard Teas in London.

For the week ahead, I'm keeping the bean theme going. I'm going to try Felicity Cloake's vegetarian chili recipe from a few weeks ago. It makes me slightly uncomfortable realizing quite how similar it is to black bean soup, though I imagine the complexity of the chilis and not using exclusively black beans will make a difference. I think that will make a nice lunch for at least a few days during the week.

Summer is well and truly here, so I'm leaning in on summery food for dinner, even if I'm still trying to keep inside for public health reasons. Eating outdoors doesn't usually seem like such an exceptional treat, and yet here we are.

Assuming the great pasta shortage of 2020 has resolved itself and I can get some good spaghetti or other long pasta, I'm in the mood for some spaghetti alle vongole. This also presupposes I can get littleneck clams. I may have to settle for mussels. Though that's not really much of a consolation prize if I'm honest. If push comes to shove, I'd go mussels over clams any day. For rhetorical purposes, though, spaghetti alle cozze doesn't have the same currency. That needs something vegetable to go with it. If I were willing to be more uncouth I'd do corn on the cob. Instead I'll be very orthodox and do something like a bruschetta with roasted peppers and good olive oil. What is air conditioning for if not to let you bake your own bread in any weather?

Summer also makes me think tacos for whatever reason. I did fish tacos a couple of weeks ago, and for some variety I'm going to do carnitas. Here again I turn to Felicity Cloake for a primer. I'll probably take her serving suggestion and serve with a red cabbage-carrot salad, though I may round it off with some roasted sweetcorn as well.

Finally, I'm going to return to an old-new favorite: the white wine and miso marinated salmon from chef Taku Sekine. It's so easy, and so incredibly good. Part of me wants to give myself the night off and do something incredibly easy like steaming some haricots verts and tossing them with lemon, olive oil, and sea salt. The more ambitious part of me wants to do a smashed cucumber salad. I realize the fish has a Japanese cant and the cucumber salad is more Chinese. I feel like it works. Knowing myself, without anyone other than myself to cook for or impress, I'll probably take the easy path.

For something sweet, the weather makes me think strawberries. Fingers crossed I can get good fresh strawberries. If not, I may draw on my stash of frozen berries. Either way, I'm in the mood for an Eton mess. Any political commentary is incidental.

As ever, I'd love your feedback. If you're enjoying this, please recruit your friends!

Stay hungry,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 13
Content:
Hello again from confinement,

It's now been possible to return to restaurants for about two weeks here in Massachusetts. Of course, this lifting of confinement restrictions came with virtually no notice and only allows restaurants to open with outdoor seating, so many places aren't ready or simply can't reopen. There's also the fact I want this to be over for real, and thus don't want to become a disease vector. If the public health situation remains stable by the end of next week, perhaps I'll venture outside.

In the meantime, it's still lots and lots of cooking at home.
As predicted, it wasn't really practical to do the spaghetti con vongole. My local Whole Foods wanted $6 for an entire kilo of mussels and 75 cents for each littleneck clam. I have no objection to paying serious money for serious ingredients, but this was a bridge too far. Littleneck clams aren't amazing in the same way as black truffle or even really good olive oil. So instead, I used muscles and did the pasta alle cozze. Definitely a success.
The carnitas made for some excellent tacos too. It's a surprisingly easy technique, even if it takes a fair bit of time to let the pork simmer away. I improvised a salsa rosa, and the carrot-cabbage salad was a very good idea indeed.
My Eton mess was a bit of a mess. Mostly because I managed to wind up with a defective pint of cream. It was solid in the jug: more of a proto-butter than cream. Not that there's really that much to complain about when it comes to crisp-soft meringue with macerate red fruits.
For the week ahead, I have to use some salmon. Usually by this time of the year it's possible to get fresh-caught wild salmon from my seafood counter. It's yet to arrive, so I've kept buying big packs frozen wild salmon from the freezer case. It's so much better than the weird farmed stuff. Now that supplies have improved, I'm hoping I can get some green lentils and do a preparation I tried to do earlier in the condiment: poached salmon with warm lentils. I didn't really "get" this concept until I had it last winter at one of my now-favorite brasseries in Paris. It's not really the right season, but thinking of that meal, I'm reminded of the lovely charred leek with vinaigrette that I had as a first course. All of which really has to be eaten with some good bread.It's warm now, but not hot-hot, so I'm not quite ready for vichyssoise or gazpacho. Though I'm continuing my tour of food from warmer climes. I'm going to start with jerk chicken. Invariably I won't be able to get my hands on a scotch bonnet pepper for the marinade, but honestly that might be for the best: my tolerance for spicy food is pretty low. Sadly, I'm going to have to do the chicken in the oven rather than on a grill outside. I'll serve that with basmati rice and honey-glazed roast carrots.

Making a giant batch of basmati rice will also let me try out a novel recipe for Mediterranean fried rice from the always lovely Yotam Ottolenghi. Fortunately, no pomegranate seeds required. As previously mentioned, I'm a big fan of anchovy dressings.

For lunch, I'm continuing my hybrid takeout-cook-at-home approach. The takeout menu remains more or less the same — I will not be returning to the cheap and cheerful sushi place that gave me low-sodium shoyu — and the at-home menu will be a return of the scallion pancakes. I'm also giving a bit of a lesson on whipping those together to some folks.

Great strawberries are still nonexistent at my local Whole Foods, so I'm continuing to rely on frozen. But the weather is right for it, and frozen strawberries can be great. After the slight Eton mess disaster, I'm going to try this rather fetching deconstructed strawberry and lemon balm tart. It goes without saying I'm not optimistic about getting my hands on any lemon balm or even fresh currants. That's not going to stop me from doing something in this vein.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you! Feedback is very much appreciated, and please share with your friends as we navigate the slow return to something at least approaching normalcy.

Stay hungry,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 14
Content:
Hello and happy summer dear readers,

This comes to you a day later than normal. In doing a bit of DIY a few days ago, I managed to completely destroy the right side of my body, which has made even typing more difficult than I would have guessed. It turns out using a hammer drill to make a hole in concrete is pretty physically demanding. You'll also have to forgive a slightly more abridged version than usual: I'm attempting to write this using almost exclusively my left hand.

At any rate, the last week was its usual swings and roundabouts. The more Mediterranean-angled fried rice that I mentioned last time was definitely a success. The addition of lemon peel is, I think, what took it over the top. I may need to up the portion size to make it a complete meal, but that's hardly a real complaint. I also had some real success with the bread I baked to go with my brasserie-inspired salmon-lentil-leek combination. It was the first baguette I managed to produce with the right interior crumb.
Less pleasingly, my local Whole Foods was out of Puy lentils. While, I'm usually very skeptical of protected origin products, and I'm sure there are people somewhere making very good or even superior Puy-style lentils, the Eden Organic green lentils my store did have were not as good as the real thing. I'm still working on getting my whole roasted leeks up to the standard of the place where I realized the potential of the leek as a star of the show.

It is finally well and truly hot here. In a less confused world that might mean having cool summer food outside in the heat. Alas, I have to do it indoors and pretend. But it is time to haul out the real summer fare.

I haven't done a lot of drinks ideas here, though now is as good a time as any to start. I'm planning to ride out the heat wave with a summer cup. There's a part of me that wants to go the extra mile on this and make my own spirit blend, but I so strongly associate this with Pimm's, I'll probably pick up a bottle of No 1 for these purposes.

For food, I'm putting a real focus on light, warm weather fare. I think it's time to do some pan bagnat, the classic tuna sandwich from the PACA region of France. I'm not usually big on tuna sandwiches. I can't quite figure out whether I love the pan bagnat because the whole concept is great, or because I bother to get really good tuna when I make it.

Keeping with the same theme, I'm also planning to do a gazpacho. It's a pretty forgiving soup that will work with most tomatoes, but I'm hoping I can get my hands on some seriously good heirloom varieties for an extra hit of complexity. That's not quite enough to make a meal, so, at the risk of cultural confusion, I'm planning to pair that with some bruschetta. 

Finally, I'm hoping I can get my hands on some nice striped bass and oven roast that with some white wine and mushrooms. I'm trying to keep things simple, so I'll likely serve that with some polenta and perhaps a shaved fennel salad.

Tying back to the summer cup, I thought for a sweet this week I'd toss together some kind of fruit trifle. I don't know whether it's the pandemic or the general decline of post-Amazon Whole Foods, but I've yet to see the really amazing locally-sourced summer fruit for sale yet. I may yet have to content myself with the frozen stuff, in which case I'll probably do something raspberry-inclined.

Going against my very southern European theme for the week, I'm planning to make a big batch of pad Thai and do that for lunch with supplements from my local favorite lunch spots. I still have the world's largest block of tamarind in my refrigerator ready to go.

If the public health trend here remains as good as it's been for the last month, I may finally venture out to a restaurant, assuming the weather cools down a bit. Evidence suggests being indoors with the air conditioning running is about the worst place to be when there's an airborne virus floating around.

As ever, if you're enjoying this, I'd love to hear from you and hear what you've been doing to keep yourself fed as we continue to fight this disease. And if you're enjoying this, please tell your friends! Having an audience is definitely motivating.

Stay hungry,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 15
Content:
Hello dear readers,

Sadly, my right arm still isn't quite right, so this will once again be slightly more abbreviated and not quite up to the same level of production value as I had achieved in some of the more recent dispatches. If you really are only reading this for the photos, you can get the slightly less polished stream of food photos from my Instagram account.

The past week I've been in a bit of a culinary funk. Partly due to a lack of inspiration, partly, I suspect, due to a certain amount of mediocre execution. I love pan bagnat, but my brilliant idea to combine pan bagnat with continued baguette refinement and execution did not do me any favors. That sandwich really needs a soft, squishy bread with a bit of width that can really take the pile of delicious fixings that go inside. For the pad Thai, I somehow managed to forget to buy several key ingredients, which made for something not bad, but also not great.
Strawberries were the one bright spot. I finally managed to get my hands on some really excellent local berries, and they were amazing. For me by myself, I eventually decided that doing an entire trifle was a bit too much, and wound up doing shortcakes instead. I hadn't made shortcakes in years, and realized that they're scones by another name. I tried macerating the berries in some gin along with the sugar and a pinch of salt. I'm not sure I could really detect the juniper, but it also definitely didn't detract from the wonderful berries.

For the week ahead, I'm trying to regain some of my confidence with a bit more experimentation.

As it's the Fourth of July in a few days, I thought I could make burgers, albeit indoors in a pan. I don't have any special affinity for burnets, but it does give me a chance to try making my own burger buns, which should be interesting.

Keeping with the summery theme, I'm going back to PACA and doing a sort of riff on bouillabaisse, the traditional dish from Marseilles. It comes from Eric Ripert, who runs the truly amazing Bernardin seafood restaurant in New York, via Kenji López-Alt over at Serious Eats. I thought about making a more classic bouillabaisse, but it's another one of those dishes I have difficulty finding the motivation to toss together without a group of other people to impress.

I recently discovered the excellent Alex YouTube channel, which manages to combine my interests in food, engineering, and Gallic culture in one convenient place. His most recent series has been about modifying his domestic oven to achieve the temperatures needed to make really good Neopolitan-style pizza. I'm not about to slice open my oven, but it's got me in the mood to do pizza again. It's also a great excuse to pick up some prosecco. For newer readers, my reference pizza dough recipe is from Ken Forkish. His pizza place is a favorite.

Finally, I'm going to take my attention back to working on doing great gnocchi. I found another tutorial from an accomplished Tuscan chef with a more minimal approach that feels more in line with my general approach to food. No fussy ridged rolling board required. He rolls the dough into a snake with minimal additions, and simply cuts with a knife. I'm going to pair this batch of gnocchi with a white wine and mushroom sauce.

For something sweet, I felt the need to try something not made with strawberries, but still with a summery feel. While it's not exactly light — there's lots of cream involved — I love a lemon posset. That could easily be combined with some macerated raspberries, blueberries, or really any other summer fruit. I have my fingers crossed I can get something other than strawberries that weren't grown for shipping en masse in Watsonville.

Stay hungry and have a great long weekend,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 16
Content:
Hello readers,

Slowly, slowly, I'm venturing outside. I've now done a couple of lunches out and survived to tell the tale. On the other hand, dining out in the pandemic era lacks some of the conviviality of whatever we were doing before. I'm still not willing to dine out more than once a week, and there's no way I'm going to eat indoors or with more than one or two other people. I'm still doing a lot more cooking at home than usual.

Along those lines, for anyone French inclined, I ordered a copy of À la maison, a fun little cookbook project that puts together a few dozen confinement recipes from many big names in food to raise money for a food security charity. I've begun to exhaust DIY projects, and it has crossed my mind to turn my hand to putting together some kind of cookbook.

From the week that's been, it will come as no surprise that there were some victories and some real losses. It turns out that a chef who runs a fancy restaurant in Tuscany may have some intuitive judgement that I don't. Which is to say that my attempt at making minimalist gnocchi was a pretty serious failure. My hunch is that I needed to dry out the riced potatoes. Likewise my riff on a French fish stew was a little too heavy on tomatoes.
My burger buns were excellent, however. There will inevitably be a time that I'll need to buy some pre-made burger buns again in the future, but this is my new normal. The tangzhong method is incredibly easy, and other than that small complication, making buns is a lot easier than something like a baguette.

With the pizza, since I have to get the oven really hot anyway, I decided to do a Café Miznon-style cauliflower. It's an incredibly simple preparation, but possibly the best way to do cauliflower.

Moving ahead, I'm taking another stab at Indian cuisine with a chicken biryani. I don't know enough about Indian food to figure out if this is really seasonal. It's a fairly light, aromatic dish. But it's also cooked almost like a stew, which doesn't feel especially summery to me. On the other hand, the weather in, say, Delhi in January is about the same as it is here in the summer. Irrespective, it's good eating.

Taking inspiration from one of my recent adventures in dining out, I'm also thinking of doing more tacos. If for no other reason than that I'm bored, I'm thinking of doing tacos in the style of a fish taco, but substituting tofu for the fish. I had some tofu tacos (let it be said, alongside some chorizo tacos) on one of my recent lunches out, and they were really quite good.

Continuing my slightly confused stumbling through disparate parts of the food world, I'm thinking of taking a stab at curried Singapore noodles. In all honesty, I started exploring the various characteristic dishes of Singapore after reading Kevin Kwan's Crazy Rich Asians novels, and this wound up being a favorite. I'm sure neither my home version nor anything I've ever had at a restaurant in the United States holds a candle to the street food of Malaysia, but it's good enough for me for a weeknight dinner.

For lunches in, I'm very tempted to do more black bean burgers, if only as an excuse to make more tangzhong burger buns.

Assuming I can get more excellent summer fruit, I'm thinking of tossing together a galette for something sweet. They have a lot of the drama of a fancy tart or other impressive dessert, but with a lot less work.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you! And for the millionth time, I'll make another plug for myself and suggest you share this with your friends if you're enjoying it.

Stay hungry,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 17
Content:
Hello readers,

Over four months into this project, I have to admit I feel my enthusiasm fading a little bit. There's a part of me that wants to end the series and go back to cooking a little less publicly. But on the other hand, even the fairly limited audience I'm speaking to here has been useful for motivating me to try new things and tinker around. At the point I still have to eat, and I do't really have a lot else to do, I've realized I might as well keep it going.

That said, I have taken some of my other time and taken to reviving a project to put together a cookbook. We'll see how far I get. If you've ever felt cheated by the fact I link to recipes rather than sharing what I actually do, then perhaps this will be for you.

But back to our normal business. The past week has been a little rough food-wise mostly because my neighborhood Whole Foods had mysterious shortages of just the ingredients I needed. They were completely out of thin rice noodles and the good frozen shrimp for the Singapore-style curried noodles. Even more surprising, they had no tofu for my not-fish fish tacos.Fortunately I had some leftover tofu, so I was able to try the concept once. The beer batter was great, though I clearly need to get a probe for my thermometer that makes it easier to monitor the temperature of the fry oil. Periodically having to dip a probe in was rather perilous. I'd still prefer fish tacos with actual fish, but the fried tofu really was a pretty acceptable substitute in my continuing effort to lower the carbon footprint of my diet.

Much more successful was the biryani. The quality of the recipes that I found was more uneven than I appreciated when I tried to use them. So I had to improvise quite a bit. But now I think I understand the conceptual components of the dish, which should make it easier for me to get a real grip on. I wound up using a normal ratio of rice to water, which made the biryani less fluffy than I would have liked.
I wound up making the galette with white peaches, which was very nice. It would have been a bit better with a little something to add complexity. If I do this again, I may try adding some thyme or maybe a bit of lemon.

The week to come is going to be what one might call a refinement week. In particular, I really want to try another method (or two) for making gnocchi. They really don't seem like they should be that hard to make, and I'm confident that there's a trick I'm missing that many of the articles or videos online fail to mention. I'm going to try out the method from this post over on Serious Eats. Depending on my mood, I'll either do that with a pesto sauce or repeat the herby mushrooms that I used on my last (disastrous) attempt at gnocchi.

I'm going to try refining the saffron-tinted mussels from a few weeks ago. The last time was a little bit too heavy on tomato. They're summery and fresh. To be served, of course, with great crusty bread. I mention this again because my favorite YouTube baker has subtitled a more home cook-focused method of making baguettes at home into English.

There are also more low-carbon tacos on the docket with sweet potato tacos. While I don't follow her method exactly, I certainly take inspiration for this from Nigella Lawson's At My Table. The sweet potatoes make a nice no-meat way to do tacos. I'm not as in thrall to avocados as some people. I'll probably pair the sweet potato with a peppy salsa, quick pickle red onions, and copious amounts of fresh coriander. She has a new book, Cook, Eat, Repeat, coming later in the year that I'm eager to read.

For something sweet, I'm returning to the pavlova neighborhood. I have it in my mind to do something with raspberries, though in recent experience there won't be any truly great raspberries when I do my provisions run. The exceptional strawberries were very short-lived.

And so we conclude again for the week. As ever, I'd love your feedback, and if you're enjoying this, please tell your friends! I've realized that I am only human, and a sense of momentum does help with my motivation for keeping this going.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 18
Content:
Hello again readers,

Call this week another triumph for the scientific method. Actually getting a handle on the mechanics of why different choices make sense for making gnocchi — thanks to the post I linked to last time — I finally managed to make some halfway decent dumplings at home. I still have some work to do, mostly in terms of dithering less so the gnocchi are a little lighter. But I was very pleased.The key is moisture control. While I don't usually like russet potatoes, they have a lower water content that really works here. I also realized that I was not using anywhere near enough flour, and had taken the Italian cooks' advice a little too much to heart. Those two changes, plus baking rather than boiling the potatoes — again to drive out moisture — appear to have done the trick. They were pillowy (and look a bit like pillows), soft, and, in a big improvement versus the last attempt, they did not disintegrate when boiled.
I was pretty pleased with my mussels as well. Switching from an entire can of tomatoes to a small dash of tomato paste gave me the intensity and savoriness of tomato rather than masking all the other flavors like the saffron.The tacos were good too. I remain convinced they're not very photogenic. Believe me when I say that I tried. Maybe my standards have gotten too high. Somehow they were also slightly disappointing from a gustatory perspective. I think it's possible I left the sweet potatoes in the oven too long in the name of developing crispness. They were very crispy in the end, but didn't have much of that fluffy goodness on the inside.

Looking ahead, I'm continuing to support my local takeout places for lunch for the most part. A recent favorite was the roasted tomato and fennel soup from my friends at Flour. Less thrilling has been the perpetual temptation-denial pattern of Sweetgreen putatively bringing back their roasted tomato bowl, only to tell me every time I go to order it that they're out of roasted tomatoes.

Keeping with the weather, which is particularly scorching as I write this, I'm maintaining my focus on light summery fare.

One of my recently discovered favorites is steamed fish Vietnamese-style. First, the fish is seasoned and gently steamed. Then you generously heap aromatic herbs over the fish — I like ginger and cilantro — and douse the whole thing in hot oil to bring out the flavor of the garnishes. It seemed kind of crazy to me when I first read about it, but it's not really as dangerous as it sounds (though I do it in the kitchen rather than at the table), and it really does bring out the flavor of the herbs. I'd love to use striped bass for this, though I'll probably have to settle for something in the freezer case. This would go well with any manner of things, but I'm probably going to pair it with steamed rice and braised greens with a hit of garlic and shallot to go with the fish.

For something slightly more substantial, I'm going to try out a chicken and chickpea tagine. It is very stew-like, but it's also fairly light, and something about the fact it comes from the Maghreb makes me feel like it does go with this weather after all. This of course has to be served with couscous. It's probably entirely nonsensical if I were trying to make the pairing food culturally coherent, but I really want to serve this with some artichokes in a nice vinaigrette.

To round things out I'm going to try this simple recipe for beans with herbs and mozzarella from the folks over at Ducksoup in London. If we're honest this might just be a great excuse to eat more bread, but I don't really see the problem with that. I'll probably toss together a simple green salad to go alongside as well.

If I had a bigger kitchen, I'd own an ice cream machine and impress you all with my grand plans to make some scratch vanilla ice cream with a Salt and Straw-style twist. Alas, I don't, so I'm going to have to sate that need with some store-bought vanilla ice cream, very possibly paired with some grilled stone fruit, if anything looks good when I go shopping. I'll probably also pick up some ladyfingers or other light crispy biscuits. They're an easy way to improve on plain ice cream by adding a bit of texture for contrast.

There's not much end in sight for the extraordinary public health measures, so look forward to another edition next weekend. As ever, I'd love to hear from you with feedback or ideas, and please share this with your friends if you're enjoying it.

Stay hungry,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 19
Content:
Hello again,

As I get deeper into the art of taking photos of what I'm cooking, I'm beginning to feel like the wardrobe director with big dreams on a low-budget TV show. My general approach to buying kitchen equipment and tableware is to buy quality over quantity. This has the byproduct that most of what I own looks pretty good in photos, except that I feel like I'm repeating myself. Most of my tableware is white porcelain that goes with anything. Most of my cookware is All-Clad that looks exactly the same whether it's a tiny frying pan or a giant stock pot. I'm getting uncomfortably close to the point of really going off the deep end and buying off cuts of different exotic kitchen countertop materials as props. Though I think it would be too off-brand to buy a piece of Star Wars-themed Le Creuset.

Food-wise, the big highlight was my experiment with yet another riff on the North African tagine. As I was cooking, the idea of tossing many, many handfuls of dried figs into a chicken braise seemed crazy. The result was surprisingly excellent. The figs help thicken the sauce and add a nice sweet-savory tang.
My summer fruit expectations on my weekly shopping trip were once again not met. Rather than buy mediocre peaches, I bought some above-average (though not off-the-charts amazing) strawberries to deplete my remaining stash of par-baked shortcake. It was good, even if I felt somewhat unoriginal.For the vegetarian main, I used the last of my stock of excellent Rancho Gordo beans. Tossing beans, cheese, and herbs together is simple enough that the quality of the beans really comes through. It also gave me a chance to enjoy one of the good olive oils I have kicking around.

Looking ahead, I have the perhaps chimerical hope that I can get my hands on some really good cherry tomatoes and do a spaghetti pomodorini. Something about the idea of eating nothing but pasta for dinner does not work for me, so I'll pair that with something like a second course of grilled eggplant. Possibly involving a miso glaze, cultural dissonance aside. The spaghetti with small tomatoes also makes a nice light lunch on its own.

Given it's going to be unbelievably hot again in the next few days, I'm also going to return to the no-cook pan bagnat from a few weeks ago. Last time I tried to do it on a baguette, and it didn't quite take. The bread is too crusty and narrow for the mass of ingredients that are piled on. My thought is to continue using the same dough, but shape it into some kind of square individual portion and bake it a little shy of what I'd typically do.

As ever, I have a giant pile of frozen salmon in my freezer that I feel like I need to use. It's also possible that my local Whole Foods will finally have fresh wild salmon in stock. I don't really have any grand aspirations for the fish. I'll simply grill it, and serve it by itself. My experiment for the week will be with toum via Yotam Ottolenghi's regular column in the Guardian. I'm not sure I'll do a broad bean salad as he suggests; that will depend on what I find when I go shopping.

Moving into the sweet portion of the plan, I feel like once again this will hugely depend on my level of enthusiasms for the summer fruit on offer. It may be time for me to resurrect the project to recreate the best peach tart I've ever eaten. (To be extremely clear, the linked recipe is not the tart in question, which was in fact at an extremely nondescript café on the side of a very uninteresting road on the outskirts of Nice, France. Though the Ottolenghi recipe is very good.) It may be that I'm so unenthusiastic I'll make some coconut macaroons, which have the topical air and hot weather-appropriateness from the coconut, but do not force me to use uninspiring summer fruit for the sake of it.

I'll be back again next week with another installment. Sadly, if anything the public health situation is getting worse, not better, even here in reasonably sane Massachusetts. I'd love your feedback if you're enjoying this, and I'd also heartily encourage you to share this with your friends if you're enjoying it.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 20
Content:
Hello again,

The confinement and thus the confinement cooking continues. If anything, it looks like my pessimism was well-judged, even here in reasonable Massachusetts. The idea of renting a house on a beach somewhere hasn't been entirely ruled out. Though the more I think about it, the more I realize the cost is less of a problem than having to live somewhere with limited restaurant options and a completely unknown kitchen. So at least for now there will be no photos from a photogenic kitchen in Edgartown.Whereas I can now call myself a fan of this levantine dressing called toum that I found in the Ottolenghi column a few weeks ago. It's really nothing more than extremely potent garlic oil. If you like garlic, however, as I avowedly do, it's fantastic. I wound up doing lima beans (I take what I can get) with shaved fennel, tarragon, and mint. It was very nice. Also handy that it requires very minimal cooking at the height of summer.The miso eggplant was a bit underwhelming. My execution seemed not so much bland as kind of dilute; as if the glaze needed to be concentrated more, or the eggplant needed more time to become one with the glaze. That or jamming the eggplant under the grill obliterated something. On my second attempt I let the glaze sit on the eggplant for at least half an hour before tucking in to no avail. There was a run on good spaghetti, so I wound up going more whimsical and using gemelli for the pasta component to go with the eggplant.I picked up some locally produced blueberries to do a quick crumble. My feeling was very neutral. They were fine. Aside from the one batch of strawberries a few weeks ago, nothing has really hit me over the head with amazingness this summer. Perhaps this is further evidence of Whole Foods's decline under the reign of King Bezos.
My devotion to the fine people at Flour Bakery and Café for lunch has reached a new level. In the couple of months since they reopened I've been often enough that I now qualify for a free tote bag. Of course what I really want is to throw them more money if they would only bring back the smoked salmon sandwich.

Looking ahead, I'm eagerly awaiting the arrival of my copy of À la maison, if only to have a new source of inspiration to cook from. On the other hand, it's shipping from either France or the Netherlands, which, given the state of the world, may mean it won't be here until September. I recently put in an order to restock tea from my favorite tea shop, Postcard Teas. The parcel has been tied up in some kind of customs limbo for a few days now. They're really lovely people, and have miraculously survived the pandemic intact. Their products are excellent and not all that much more expensive than buying "nice" teabags at a grocery store. If you're into tea, I'd highly recommend giving them some support.

In the meantime, the latest Ottolenghi column in the Guardian features a stew that looked interesting. Summer doesn't usually seem like stew season to me, but who am I to disagree with the esteemed Yotam? The zing of lemon and the softness of dumplings sounds excellent to me, so I'm going to give his lemon chicken with dumplings a try.

Whether it's summery I'm not sure, but something has put me in the mood for risotto. My staple shellfish and squid has been in short supply when I've looked on my weekly shopping run, but I'm crossing my fingers that they'll have what I need. I'm in half a mind to pair that with more vegetables tossed with my copious leftover levantine garlic sauce.

Keeping with the if not summery then plucked-from-a-culture-in-a-hot-climate theme, I'm going to give myself a break and do fajitas. They offer great return on effort. When I do a stir fry, it winds up taking forever. I have to make rice, cut up lots of different vegetables, maybe some garlic, make a sauce, and I'm always disappointed because my circa 1980 cooktop doesn't have enough power to get the pan as hot as it needs to be. Whereas fajitas really do only require cutting up a few vegetables, prepping some kind of protein, and I'm really not that bothered if the vegetables get a little too soft. That said, I'll probably do something veggie, perhaps with marinated portobello mushrooms instead of steak.

For a sweet, I'm still not ready to make my annual attempt at recreating the mythical peach tart from the nondescript roadside café. For that reason, I'll probably commit to doing coconut macaroons this time. Unless I go into the store and my expectations are exceeded with some amazing local raspberries. I'd love an excuse to do a raspberry panna cotta with a hit of grappa.

That's all for this week. I'll be back again next week. It will be fun (if depressing in its way) to get into some fall recipes in a few weeks when the weather begins to turn. As ever, I'd love your feedback, and please feel free to share with your friends!

Until next time,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 21
Content:
Hello again excellent readers,

In my confinement cycle, I feel like I'm in another food plateau week. It feels weirdly routine, even as the strange slow-fast pandemic time ticks forward. It's not good, though neither is it bad. It's very neutral, and I don't know how to feel about that.

The coconut macaroons were all swings and roundabouts. On balance, they were good. I didn't get all the details right, and I have some perhaps more fundamental issues with the recipe. The coconut was too toasted. It's unclear to me what I did wrong there. My oven is pretty well-calibrated and I don't think the shredded coconut was especially exotic. Yet I felt like the coconut was way too rather than a little too toasted. Though my bigger issue was with the evaporated milk. Something about it gave the macaroons a wet sock bad funk rather than, say, an alluring aged cheese funk. The amount of sugar has slightly put me off the concept as well. It may be a few months before I return to this and work out the kinks.

My risotto was once again disrupted by what I assume are supply chain issues due to the pandemic. Much to my dismay they didn't have the shellfish I wanted for the risotto at my friendly neighborhood Whole Foods. Instead, I bought what turned out to be a literal slab of frozen squid. It was impossible to separate before thawing, which necessitated some improvisation, lest the tubes and tentacles go to waste.
In the end, I tossed together some squid fajitas. While it was reasonably good, I'm not sure I'd wholeheartedly recommend the concept. It wasn't helped by my lack of forethought. The squid really needed to sit uncovered in the refrigerator for a day to wick away surface moisture. Too much of the squid steamed rather than seared.

Doing dumplings in the height of summer was a bridge too far, whatever Yotam says. Instead, I took the opportunity to make another run at the baguette with the lemon chicken less dumplings. Cranking the oven to 450 °F isn't especially summery either, but at least culturally the baguette is a year-round food.

Moving into next week, continuing with the bread theme I have it in my head to do some tartines for lunch a couple of afternoons. Given the time of year, it should be something with hits of basil and tomatoes. Though as ever either because Whole Foods has gone too downmarket or supply chains are disrupted, I have yet to encounter any amazing tomatoes.

For my usual veggie option I'm going to try doing a Spanish omelette. As that's mostly eggs and potatoes — and I have to turn on the oven anyway — I'm tempted to do another Café Miznon-style cauliflower to go alongside. It won't photograph especially well, if I had to guess. It risks being a very beige meal. If I can summon the energy, I'll give things a visual punch (and stay on theme) with a romesco sauce.

Meanwhile, the giant pile of frozen salmon in my freezer notwithstanding, I'm sick of salmon at the moment. Maybe — maybe — if I can get my hands on some freshly-caught wild Alaskan king salmon I'll still buy some, but otherwise, I'm looking for another fish to grace my table. As ever much depends on what I can get my hands on. I like the idea of picking up some striped bass and grilling it in the oven with a verdant slather of pesto.

As I'll have to buy lots of basil for the pesto anyway, I'm minded to do more pizza. For a little variety, I'm thinking of replicating one of my favorites by tossing a giant pile of arugula on top after it comes out of the oven. It's not especially different to a normal pizza margherita, but I wouldn't want to give the impression that I'm so unoriginal. That said, it's summer, and that to me still screams pizza.

For something sweet, a friend is giving a group of people a walkthrough on these Swedish cardamom buns, or kardemummabullar. It's difficult for me to really comment on them before diving in: this will be my first time trying them out. Though I do love cardamom, so I'm optimistic. Perhaps next week I'll finally make my annual attempt at the white peach tart.

I'm always happy to hear from folks. And as ever, if you're enjoying this, please feel to share with friends.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 22
Content:
Hello again dear readers,

This is coming a bit late for a variety of reasons. First, because I wanted to include some glamour shots of the kardemummabullar mentioned last week. Though as you'll see, my shaping technique was not up to the reference version, so glamour is maybe too strong a word. Second, because I somehow managed to cook too much food. The net result of which is that I still don't really need to go shopping for more, and I'm still working through everything I made for the last week.

Speaking of which, it was yet another week of ups and downs. In a slightly exasperating way, my friendly neighborhood Whole Foods had nothing interesting at the fish counter except, as luck would have it, fresh wild-caught sockeye salmon. It was excellent, paired with the pesto.
In the end, I wound up making so much pesto that the romesco was unnecessary. My very beige but very tasty Spanish-style tortilla was very much livened up by the hit of green, not to mention the earthy-vegetal flavor of the pesto. And of course it's very hard to go wrong with the melt-in-your-mouth Miznon-style cauliflower.

The pizza was once again very satisfying, even if it's not quite up to Alex's standards. I'm not ready to take apart my oven yet, or buy one of the new products coming on the market for this purpose.
The cardamom buns were delicious. My technique, however, requires a bit of work to get the elegant swirls the recipe's author (and my expert friend who gave us a lesson) achieves. My search for cardamom seeds led me to the excellent folks at Curio Spices on the other side of the river, whose products I definitely recommend. They remind me a lot of the wonderful folks at La Boîte in New York.For the week ahead, I'm caught between excitement and despair. Excitement because summer is reaching its peak and with it more excellent produce may finally make its way onto my plate. There's also the prospect of fall around the corner with more opportunities to mix things up as I want things with a little more warmth. On the other hand, it's slightly disturbing to have now been through almost all the seasons with no end in sight to the public health crisis.

Less existentially, if my schedule permits, I may return to the bao from the height of confinement as a speedy lunch. For probably inaccurate reasons I think of them as very coming from the more tropical parts of the world, and so they have that summer appropriate-because-it's-always-hot-there angle.

For dinners, I'm going to do another white bean salad of some sort. Possibly this one with tuna from Serious Eats, perhaps with a poached egg on the side for good measure. There's a part of me that wants to mess with it more by adding some olives and green beans to make it even more of a strange remix of the salade niçoise.

With summer waning, I've suddenly become less interested in novelty and more interested in squeezing out my last opportunities to make summery dishes without feeling guilty. To that end, I'm making more seafood paella, whether you're sick of hearing about me cook rice or not. I have my fingers crossed that I don't have to buy another slab of squid this time.

As mentioned, I managed to over-prepare for the last week, so that's really all I plan to shop for. If you're looking for another idea, I was quite seduced by the recent feature on dal in the Financial Times. I've made no secret of how much I enjoy lentils. A nice dal with some good basmati rice is a real treat.

For something sweet, my yearly peach tart attempt is going to have to wait another week. Some really excellent strawberries came across my path while I was shopping for some specialty ingredients at not Whole Foods for once. This really has become the summer of the strawberry. After so much shortcake, I'm going to return to the minimalist sablé base from a recipe I gave a try at the beginning of the season.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you if you're enjoying the newsletter, and please tell your friends, too.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 23
Content:
Hello again,

Every week as I begin writing this, I have to refer back to the archive to figure out what the next number in the sequence is. Doing that this time, I realized we're almost at week 26, which marks half a year since I began confinement cooking. Sadly, the prognosis for the public health situation hasn't improved much. Though I'm reaching the point that in order to continue living my life, I may revive my kitchen renovation project that's been on hold.

That may put confinement cooking itself on hold. The idea of washing dishes in the bathroom and living out of a mini-fridge doesn't much appeal to me, even compared with living on a diet of takeout. I may spend enough to have a chance to try and possibly discover the non-obvious benefits of the Sweetgreen VIP help line. (Because fashionable salad-bowl food can go so disastrously wrong?) But that's a long way off even as I begin to bring the project out of its deep freeze.

At any rate, looking back on the week, the white bean salad was a qualified success. It's good, but lacks a certain substantialness, poached egg aside. It feels like more of a light lunch than a proper dinner main. My attempt to toss in some elements of a salade niçoise was also fine, but left me wanting a real one. After the peach tart, the Nice-style composed salad I had at a cool wine bar on my trip there a few years ago was definitely a highlight.
My paella plans were slightly thwarted by my failure to realize that I was completely out of good stock in my freezer. I came very close to buying a jar of Better Than Bouillon™ when I was shopping. In the end, paying $10 for a jar of something made with yeast extracts to simulate chicken was not appealing. I used water for the paella, and it was frankly fine. Watch out for me either roasting a chicken or trying to find bulk fish parts to make some stock in the coming weeks.
As all the shellfish that I wanted at the fish counter were thawed from frozen anyway, I opted instead for a giant bag of frozen scallops augmented with some tapas-style smoked mussels in a fashionable tin with a pull tab. I'll come to my plans for the mass of remaining scallops shortly.
In the end, the strawberries that I got my hands on were frankly so good that I couldn't even be bothered to make a pastry crust or cake to go with them. A dash of alcohol and truly minimal dusting of sugar to help draw out moisture and concentrate the flavor were all it took.
