Moving to the week to come, I'm more determined this time that I will make more bao for lunch. My improvised veggie mushroom filling is very close, but it still needs some extra zing to achieve greatness. I'm thinking cilantro and maybe a hit of acid.

With my giant bag of frozen scallops, I'm going to try my hand at a Peruvian-style ceviche. Or perhaps I'll use a more interesting fish if I can get my hands on something that seems worth cooking. I'm going to attempt to serve that with some height-of-summer corn, assuming I like what I see when I go shopping.

I'm also in the mood for some kind of pasta dish, so going to generate an excuse to buy a new block of parmesan cheese to do a spaghetti al limone. I will add that I use the recipe from the River Cafe, mentioned, but adapted in a way I cannot vouch for, on that link. It needs something else to go with it as well: I'm thinking of some kind of basic tomato salad, or perhaps some bruschetta.

Finally, in my continuing the-place-where-it's-from-is-always-hot-therefore-this-is-summery series, I'm going to try my hand at a veggie curry of some sort. I'm conspicuously not linking to a recipe here because I wasn't able to find something on a credible source that wasn't festooned with annoying advertisements. This recipe from Thomasina Miers for something completely different seemed OK, even if it's pretty far away from what I have in mind

This is going to be the week for the annual peach tart attempt. If I had or knew of the recipe, I'd certainly share it. My backup plan is this rather fetching preparation of grilled peaches with a slightly savory herby twist.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you with ideas or thoughts, and please share with your friends!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 24
Content:
Hello readers,

Another week, another set of successes and failures. This comes to you a bit later than usual once again to squeeze in a chance to get a photo of my annual attempt at doing the mythical peach tart. Unfortunately I didn't buy enough peaches, so I improvised by tossing some raspberries in as filler. Complaining about it feels a little indulgent: it would happily grace the table of the dinner party that I cannot throw for the same reasons I started this newsletter. But that's not the standard: I'm still not at the level of the mythical tart by the side of the road.As much as I love scallops and as much as I love ceviche, I'm not convinced that the two concepts work that well together. It wasn't a bad combination, but neither was I completely over the moon. Next time, I'll hold out for some nice striped bass or another more ceviche-compatible fish. But it did look impressive.
The lemon pasta never disappoints, nor do I ever miss a chance to buy a lump of parmesan. I was also pleasantly surprised at the quality of the tomatoes I was able to get my hands on, to the extent that I regretted not also making a trip to buy some outrageously expensive aged balsamic vinegar to really set it off. Unlike the questionable watery tomato-like products sold in the winter, they had an almost jewel-like texture on the toast. It was also a great excuse to bake a loaf of bread, and honestly I could've eaten the bruschette rubbed with a little bit of garlic without the tomato very happily.The tofu-carrot-lemongrass curry was a bit of an experiment that didn't really succeed. The curry paste I made was too heavy on red chili to the point that the lemongrass was completely drowned out. Likewise, I think the coconut milk overpowered the more nuanced flavors that had survived. It must also be said I do like tofu, but I found myself wanting something different and more substantial — not even necessarily meat or poultry — in the dish.For the week ahead, I've really run out of excuses: I was once again too lazy to make the bao for lunch over the last week. The mushroom filling is languishing in its exquisite deliciousness in my refrigerator. This is the week!

Given my slightly frustrating paella experience of a few weeks ago, I have to do a roast chicken in the week ahead. It's been long enough I'm in a roast chicken mood, and possibly more importantly, I really need to replenish my supply of seriously good chicken stock. I'm going to make some sautéd spinach and, since the oven will be on anyway, roast some potatoes. It feels a little like it's creeping into fall, but then we're creeping into the fall.

That also sets me up nicely to do some interesting things with the leftovers. I'm tempted to go down the easy path and do more fajitas. It feels like another one of those last-gasp-of-summer dishes.

For a veggie main, I'm going down the chickpea route. It's very tempting to repeat the fig tagine form a few weeks ago, and substitute a bit of extra veg and chickpeas for the chicken. But I may also branch out and try something similar if a little bit different. That will, of course, be served with couscous. It's really a shame that I don't have any preserved lemons, though it's a little too last minute to get those ready for the next week.

Going sweet, I'm clinging to summer fruit. Honestly, if I see more amazing strawberries, I may simply do more shortcake. Though it would be nice if I could get myself on something else and either do another crumble or another galette. If I'm feeling especially motivated when I do my shop, I may even buy more peaches for a second run at the tart.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you if you've got ideas or simply want to share a food concept. And please feel more than welcome to share with your friends.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 25
Content:
Hello readers,

It's a useful exercise to remind myself we're living through a once-in-a-century public health event. We've now been here for about six months, and it's easy to get complacent, or, in my case, begin to really feel that frustration that so many things have had to be put on hold or been disrupted. Welcome, in other words, to September and the dregs of summer.

The last week I kept matters alimentary estival. I wound up not making another peach tart and instead going for another blueberry crumble. It was very adequate. Perhaps there's less variance in the quality of blueberries. I did have high hopes. While there was nothing really local and completely overpriced, I was able to get my hands on some promising (and, honestly, still pretty good) blueberries from a more quality-focused operation in Québec.With the tagine, I took the more off-the-beaten-path approach that I alluded to. I think it may have been vegan, incidentally. The cauliflower was a good addition. The vegan angle may have been its downfall, however. Or at least not doing more to combat the lack of body from something like well-seared shrimp. The whole thing was kind of thin and lacked body, even after blitzing up a few spoonfuls of the stew to try and give the sauce some heft. I may try this again at some point with more of an eye in that direction.
The roast chicken and the fajitas were good. Were it not for my desperation to make some chicken stock, I might not have done the roast. When I buy any kind of animal product, I really go out of my way to buy the best and most humanely raised option possible, be that pastured-raised eggs or line-caught tuna. For all my moaning and groaning, it is nice that Whole Foods doesn't try to hide the animal welfare labels on its products. I usually buy chickens on level four of their animal welfare rating scheme. This time, I had to settle for level two. Animal welfare and environmental issues aside, I could taste the difference. I've gotten so accustomed to living in my food bubble, it was somewhat disconcerting to have a mutant chicken as I was carving it after roasting.

Brilliant planner that I am, I forgot to buy the aromatics to actually make the chicken stock with the leftover roast chicken. That will have to happen sometime in the week ahead.

I did remember to make the bao — always a good idea — though forgot to take photos. Unlike the fajitas (not very photogenic), I'm getting good at the the bao pleating, and they actually looked fairly polished. This is what happens when I'm frantically making dumplings in the middle of a weekday running back and forth to my computer.

Speaking of which, the weather here remains nice enough that I can't bring myself to give up on the summery fare for the week to come.

My copy of À la maison — the cookbook bringing together confinement recipes from chefs around France — finally arrived. Because the French have done a better job controlling the public health situation than we have stateside and the book was compiled in the height of the lockdown in the spring, many of the recipes are of that season. Though I think there are a few things that will be interesting (and season-appropriate) to try out at the border of the summer and the fall.

There's a pretty straightforward fusion recipe for rare tuna from the chef at Le Bristol that I'm going to give a try. It has that minimal-cooking summery character I'm still in the mood for. I'll pair that with something like a seared baby bok choy and rice for good measure.

As a veggie option, I'm going to try my hand at red pesto with a pesto alla trapanese over designer spaghetti I picked up a couple of weeks ago. It seemed like a good way to take advantage of the tail end of tomato season. Unlike Ligurian pesto that's made with basil and pine nuts, this is made with tomatoes and blanched almonds. I may have another stab at doing an eggplant dish to go with this as I increasingly find pasta by itself a little strange.

Finally, unless I somehow manage to get my hands on really good in-season wild-caught salmon, I'm going to deplete my stockpile of frozen fish and do salmon burgers. It also gives me another chance to haul out the burger bun recipe from a couple of months ago. The starch gelling technique really works incredibly well; unless I was really in need of something convenient, I see no reason to ever buy burger buns again.

Lunch-wise, I have it in my head to bake another nice loaf of bread and return to the tartine project. Perhaps with some smoked salmon, pickled red onion, and a light spread of cream cheese. I'm not sure how summery that is, but something about the concept appeals to me.

For something sweet, there's an interesting recipe for a fig granita also from the aforementioned cookbook that I'm hoping to try out. I may have to suffer through and buy figs from California. Not that I think of the fig as especially well-suited to the New England climate, but it feels antithetical to something even if I can't quite place it.

Much as I want the license to try more fall-inflected cooking, I'm hoping summer sticks around for a few more weeks. The challenge is good. I'll be able to coast on fall classics for the first few weeks of October, I suspect. It's when I run out of ideas that things get interesting.

In the meantime, I'd love to hear from you as ever, and please tell your friends to subscribe if you're enjoying the newsletter!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 26
Content:
Hello again readers,

The day has come: we have now reached week 26. For anyone less au fait with the number's significance, this marks half a year since our crisis really took hold and I started this newsletter. That I don't feel like we're anywhere near being done is, if nothing else, a reminder we're living through an exceptional moment in history.

On a related note, a few weeks ago I mentioned dusting off my kitchen renovation project. Given I'll be stuck at home more or less indefinitely, if I wait until the public health situation improves, it may be a long wait indeed. In the last few weeks I've been interviewing architects, and may have found someone I like enough to really get the project going. That may mean this newsletter either goes into hibernation. I may also use it to chronicle the ups and downs of living almost exclusively off takeout. If you'd like to follow along on that journey, I've resurrected a blog where you can follow along.

Moving back to food, the last week was another case of slightly flawed planning. Namely, the mutant chicken I bought wound up yielding a lot more fajita fodder than I was expecting, which wound up displacing the pesto alla trapanese. Fortunately it's easy to use up a couple of spare tomatoes and some herbs, so waste was minimal.

The salmon burgers were pretty good. Not world-changing, but decent. They'll probably enter my repertoire as another one of those dishes that's easy to knock together when supplies or willpower are limited. At least my version was not especially photogenic.
My tuna experiment was quite a bit more successful. The quasi-marinade has a nice kick. It's also fun knowing I cooked something worthy of the chef at Le Bristol. Though I need to work on execution. The recipe suggests pouring the sauce into the hot pan after searing the tuna, and letting it marinate there for an hour. My usually raw-rare tuna steak wound up being much closer to medium-well, probably because of the residual heat. Next time, the post-sear soak will happen in a bowl well off the heat. I also took some inspiration from Kenji Lopez-Alt's recent Times piece about wok hei, and made some seared baby bok choy that was really, really good. Cleaning the pan afterwards was not especially fun — perhaps I should get a carbon steel pan or even a flat-bottomed wok — but the bok choy really was good.
The smoked salmon tartine was disappointing, though for reasons due purely to my own incompetence. My Whole Foods was out of cream cheese last week. As a substitute, I bought some garlic-herb soft cheese spread. Except that rather than buy a name brand like Boursin or Rondelé, I bought the generic Whole Foods private label product. How the mighty have fallen. It's awful, and one read of the ingredient list explains why: it's not cheese! It's a strange recombined cheddar cheese product. The label proudly proclaims it's from Wisconsin, which I think gives the serious and excellent people making real cheese there a bad name. If there were an alternative to Whole Foods, I'd stop shopping there tomorrow.
Out of ennui or lack of time, I decided to eat the figs as is with a little bit of honey rather than make the granita. In a more romantic telling, the weather lost that summer edge, and I didn't feel like eating something so cold.

Looking forward to the week ahead, I've more or less given up on clinging to summer. I don't really understand what it is about the weather in New England that does this. One week I can't step outside without baking, and the next I need a sweater. It always feels like the change should be more gradual.

We'll start with the sweet: I feel like I have to do something with apples. The idea of a galette appeals to a lazy part of me. The more industrious part of me wants to pick up some puff pastry and have another attempt at recreating the legendary apple tarts from Poilâne.

A small part of me really wants to hunt down some merguez sausages and have one last summery hurrah serving those with harissa corn on the cob and couscous. I've never really looked, though neither have I ever noticed merguez on sale at a butcher's counter. It's probably not a coincidence that my spell checker thinks "merguez" is misspelled.

As a more realistic summer last hurrah, I'm going to return to my favorite moules marinière. I've extolled the joys of mussels before. If you still haven't given it a try, they're really not that hard to find or scary to cook with. The shallot-white wine sauce is a joy to mop up with fries, crusty bread, or (better still) fries and crusty bread.

Keeping more with the seasonal transition, I'm going to return to one of my favorite combinations: roasted salmon with lentils. All the better because I recently received a shipment of goods from the wonderful people at Rancho Gordo. I'm sure the people at Eden Foods are nice. Their green lentils can't hold a candle to the real Puy variety.

As a veggie option, I'm going to do a polenta with mushrooms. Something about mushrooms feels very of the upcoming season, even if I know I'm going to use dried porcini and button mushrooms grown in a warehouse somewhere in Pennsylvania. Perhaps when cèpe season really comes into full force I'll hunt down some fresh ones and do an ultra-indulgent spaghetti with fresh porcini.

I'm going to throw together a nice pasta and bean soup for lunch. Partly because it's a favorite soup, though partly because I have several kilos of dried beans to use up. At the risk of this turning into an unpaid sponsorship, the Rancho Gordo beans really are good. I have high hopes: there are the excellent beans and I have a large reserve of really good chicken stock.

As usual, I'd love your feedback, and please share with your friends if you're enjoying this.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 27
Content:
Hello readers,

I find myself in a strange whirlwind of optimism and something only a shade removed from despair. On a more personal level, I'm increasingly optimistic that my decision to engage an architectural practice was the right one. I'll have more to say on that soon. Suffice to say my creative juices are flowing. I'll be putting most of that story on my ad hoc renovation blog.

On the other hand, the writers penning the year 2020 really are hacks. I'm going to seriously deviate from the usual content to encourage you to participate in the political process. The act of voting is great. Getting more involved is even better. If you're young and can find the time, consider canvassing or volunteering as poll worker to make participating easier for others.

I'm also going to recommend some political philosophy. Yascha Mounk's The Age of Responsibility changed my worldview more than perhaps any book I've read in the last decade. David Wootton's Power, Pleasure, and Profit helps us understand how we got here. My current project is Michael Sandel's The Tyranny of Merit, in a similar vein. He and two other thinkers took on this topic on Start the Week recently. I may despair at the populist shift. That more than any policy threat is what keeps me up at night. We'll only make it worse if we don't acknowledge the legitimacy of its grievances and anxieties.

Holding everything together, there is food. This change of seasons has been a welcome change for my menu planning.
It was an excellent excuse to make more mussels. The moules marinière is such a simple recipe, it's difficult to mess up. Nor is the end of summer really any reason to stop eating mussels. But it demands a slight change of tack: richer, warmer flavors. Watch this space for a fish stew at some point as we leave summer further behind.The salmon with lentils was a more overt acknowledgement of fall's arrival. That too is difficult to really mess up. Though it's one of those dishes whose simplicity underscores the need for good ingredients. None of that weird farmed salmon from Norway. None of those imposter lentils whose color is the only similarity with the good stuff of the Puy variety.
Likewise, the other projects had a certain simplicity. The polenta with mushrooms really depends on the quality of the polenta and the mushrooms. My pasta and bean soup was infinitely enhanced with the wonders of Rancho Gordo beans. Cultured butter makes all the difference in a simple apple galette.

For the week to come, the theme continues to be liminal.

Once again in an effort to deplete my immense stock of dried beans, I'm going to do one of my other favorite soups: black bean. More than any other soup I can think of, truly great black beans really do make all the difference. The quality and richness of the cooking liquor is the difference between ho-hum and spectacular. On the one hand, it's soup with all of its cold weather warming properties. On the other hand, it makes me think of Mexican cooking and warm weather.

Staying in that region, I'm going to do some kind of enchiladas. If I can muster the willpower to hunt down the right chilis (admittedly pretty unlikely), the idea of finally trying my hand at a true mole really appeals to me. More realistically, I'll probably do something predictable and dull like a basic enchiladas verdes.

Shifting more towards temperate climates and a more autumnal feeling, I'm going to venture into one of my few approved British dishes, fish pie. It's really a winning formula. There's the rich cream sauce, the flaky fish, and the topping of buttery mashed potatoes. I'll probably balance it out with some kind of autumn-winter squash. It's a little incongruous. A handful of peas in the pie does not a balanced meal make, however.

Returning to the bean theme, I'm going to round things out with another Yotam recipe: confit chickpeas. I'm not really sure what season these belong to. The perils of borrowing from a tradition that grew out of a tropical part of the world without temperate climate seasons. I'll tell myself that steaming is very warming and cozy when I make the rice.

For something sweet, I can't quite give up on fruit desserts. The really indulgent chocolate cakes have to wait for the dead of winter. In that line of thinking, I'm going to revive an old favorite and do a raspberry polenta cake. It's made with enough butter, maybe I can convince myself it's not so summery after all.

As usual, I'd love to hear from you if you're enjoying the newsletter. Please feel free to share with friends!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 28
Content:
Hello readers,

I have had a bit of a rough week. Without getting into too much detail, I need to do a better job saying "no" to projects. As it relates to this newsletter, this has meant a bit more takeout than usual. This seems important to share. Putting aside the relatively small amount of work that goes into writing and taking photos for this, all this cooking does require time and energy as well as skill. Sometimes it's not feasible, and I don't think there's anything wrong with that. For the same reason — at least before it became a lot harder to eat out — I had been becoming a lot more comfortable with the idea that restaurants didn't have to dazzle me. Sometimes you need a night off, however calming mechanically stirring a risotto may be.
That said, I did whip up some reasonable enchiladas. I definitely didn't have the time to make a mole, and also couldn't find tomatillos to do enchiladas verdes. Not that tomato-based enchiladas are really that disappointing. Keeping with what I think of as a Mexican (or perhaps Tex-Mex) theme, I also did wind up throwing together the black bean soup.For anyone in my neck of the woods, I did at least have some fun in my exhaustion and tried out Oisa Ramen. The soup suffered from being transported in a plastic container for 20 minutes. It was only really acceptable, not amazing, though I'm slightly reserving judgement for the day when I'm able to try their fare at its peak at the noodle bar.

The week ahead, then, is somewhat dictated by the week that's passed. I'd still like to catch up and do what I missed out on due to some flavor of exhaustion.

That begins with a fish pie. My motivations remain the same, perhaps underscored by the weather giving us its final gasp of summer and really settling into fall. Cream sauce and mashed potatoes are pretty great.

Likewise, I'm really eager to try out the Ottolenghi recipe for confit chickpeas that I linked to last week. I'm so eager that I bought some boutique pita bread from the fine people at Clover Food Lab. Much to my amazement, I was unable to find even boring pita bread at my local Whole Foods. I never completely rule out having not found it in their labyrinthine aisles, but it also feeds my Jeff Bezos ruined Whole Foods narrative.

For a third menu, I'm going to continue depleting my apparently bottomless supply of frozen salmon by doing a roasted salmon with harissa. It has a little bit of a North African feel that maybe isn't too seasonal, but I need to do something new. In more of a nod to the season, I'll probably pair that with carrots blasted with heat from a hot oven. I like them almost overcooked, with a nice bit of char on the outside, and so much moisture cooked out the flavor is super-concentrated and they melt in the mouth.

For a sweet, I'm going to return to the raspberry polenta cake that I didn't get around to either.

With any luck, October should be a little smoother, and my food-wise creativity will have a little more space to run. It will probably be the last gasp for home cooking before the construction crew descends and my kitchen turns into, at least initially, a pile of dust.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you, and please feel free to share this with your friends.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 29
Content:
Hello readers,

I come to you this week calmed and much more refreshed. The cooking has been back to its usual tempo, and I have my usual triumphs and failures.

From a more macro perspective, the clock is now ticking for either a hiatus or slight subject change for this newsletter. On Friday I signed the paperwork with an architectural practice to get my kitchen project started. I'll have more to say about that elsewhere at some point. I'm still not sure how I'm going to work around that. It's very possible I'll spend enough at Sweetgreen to find out what it's like to have access to their concierge service for loyal customers. The mystery of what benefit that could possibly provide is almost motivation enough by itself.

The week that's been began with the confit chickpeas. The Rancho Gordo chickpeas are fantastic. The confit chickpeas are also good. They are not, however, sufficient for anything other than maybe a light lunch. It felt like more of a part of a good mezze spread than something that could hold its own as the true center of a feast.
Harissa continues to be one of my favorite things. It almost seems like a cheat to suggest it as a recipe addition, given how excellent it is, in this case slathered on some salmon. My fish pie was a little less successful. I couldn't get the mash on top to catch for those crispy peaks — possibly I should've used a piping bag — and it bled a little too much into the sauce and seafood below. On the other hand, it was still pretty tasty.
Looking to the week ahead, I wound up making so much fish pie that I should have lunch covered for the next few days. For anyone looking for an idea, I will once again make the recommendation for a nice tartine.

On a whim I tried a carrot-blueberry muffin from my friends at Clover Food Lab a few weeks ago. I'm a convert. So why not have a try at making my own? There are a few places where the Clover muffins don't quite work for me. The strussel-esque topping is too easy to delaminate from the "body" of the muffin. It's been frustrating trying to find a recipe as a jumping off point. Predictably, this formula is a big hit with the dubious health benefits brigade. All I care about is getting that super moist crumb.

Heading savory, I'm going to drag out the classic ragù bolognese for a pasta outing. At this point, I've entered Italian grandmother territory. I make it by feel more than anything. As ever, I feel the need to eat something more than only pasta as a meal. I'll probably throw together a light salad. Possibly something with arugula and shaved parmesan.

In my continuing effort to work through my stockpile of beans, I'm going to have a run at making cassoulet. I slightly worry that I'm embracing the cold weather a little too aggressively. And I know I'm offending someone in Toulouse by even contemplating the omission of confit duck or adding Spanish sausage.

For a veggie option, I'm going to do cauliflower katsu, though possibly not follow the Jamie Oliver recipe to the letter. I'm not sure which season this corresponds to exactly, but it seemed like an interesting twist on something I usually do with chicken or pork, without lapsing into too much meat fakery.

Given I'm making muffins and probably doing a big bread bake to go with the cassoulet, I wasn't planning to make anything sweet. If you're looking for something, the chocolate-ginger cookies in the latest Honey and Co recipe in the FT looked pretty tasty.

As usual, I'd love to hear from you if you're doing something interesting or have a piece of feedback. And please feel free to share this with friends if you're enjoying it.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 30
Content:
Hello readers,

There's still not a particularly firm date for the beginning of my cooking hiatus. I suspect it's going to take at least another few months before the construction team moves in and my tiny apartment is turned into a cloud of dust.

My transition to fall has been a little rocky food-wise. I can do a ragù in my sleep in this point. It's always satisfying, if not particularly stimulating from a variety or originality perspective. Whereas my more experimental takes were edible, if disappointing.
The carrot muffins looked a little sad: I should have portioned larger amounts of batter. More importantly, they were a little flat in terms of their seasoning. I didn't have any dates on hand (as called for in my starting point recipe), so the muffins lacked the sweetness those would have provided. They also could have used some lemon zest and a pinch of salt. But they were headed in the right direction. A second attempt, and I think I'd get them more or less right.Meanwhile, the riff on cassoulet was close to an unmitigated disaster. The beans were fantastic, and that's about it. It was otherwise a red-grey slick of grease. While I'm not a cassoulet expert, I've had it often enough at restaurants to know that it can be superb, and this was not. This is much the way with these traditional French dishes. I've had similar experiences with quenelles: mine are pretty mediocre, whereas I had a superbly executed example at a neighborhood restaurant in Lyon earlier in the year. It's not light food, nor should it be. The trick is getting something rich to taste etherial.

I'll have to report back later on the cauliflower katsu. I haven't had a chance to try that out yet. Perhaps it will be the culinary savior of this week when I get to whip it up.

Looking toward the week to come, I won't give up on the carrot-blueberry muffins. A second attempt should give me a nice breakfast treat, and I think I can get the smaller details right a second time around.

For lunches, it's back to tartines. I'm thinking of doing a veggie riff on one of my usual favorites, a curried chicken salad. Given everything kind of gets turned into a paste anyway to be tartine-compatible, I think it might be possible to get away with swapping in some wonderfully creamy chickpeas.

Moving to the evenings, I'm thinking of doing a Sicilian-style fish stew as the weather begins to really transition into something autumnal. The rich tomatoey warmth with the tender fish is really quite nice. Probably paired with either bread or wet polenta, and a simple green salad much like the one from last week.

Staying with my inadvertent Italian theme, I'm going to try out the latest in Felicity Cloake's Perfect series with her take on pasta with mushrooms. The idea of whizzing up the dried porcini to make a paste and therefore intensity their flavor is a curious one that I could see working very well.

Not satisfied with something katsu-esque once in two weeks (or indeed two Guardian recipes in one), I'm also intrigued by the latest Ottolenghi recipe for a curried butternut squash gratin. He suggests pairing it with a green vegetable. I'm very tempted to be lazy and blast some broccoli with heat in the already-hot oven. Only a question of adding some slivered garlic, salt, olive oil, and a dash of lemon zest after it comes out of the oven.

I'm tempted to skip a sweet for this week for a change. I love cake as much as the next person, but it's almost like I need to clear my dessert palate to move into the slightly richer cold-weather dessert genre. If I do wind up doing a sweet — not something to be ruled out entirely — it will probably be the Christian Constant chocolate mousse from À la maison. His more informal restaurant, Café Constant, is one of the few tourist traps in Paris worth paying a visit.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you if you have a question or indeed a comment. And please feel free to share with your friends!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 31
Content:
Hello readers,

Next week I should have slightly more to say about the kitchen. For now, the end date for the 1980s kitchen will continue looming as a very exciting and expensive unknown.

In other news, I'm not making any of the recipes, but it's worth nothing — purely for the quality of the prose — that Nigella Lawson has a small sampling of recipes from her new cookbook in this weekend's Observer. My copy of the new book, Cook, Eat, Repeat, should arrive around its publication date at the end of the month. It promises to be much more like her first book, How to Cook, which has an excellent prose-recipe ratio. I do love her chocolate cake recipe, but otherwise I genuinely buy the books for the writing.

Returning to last week, I finally made the cauliflower katsu. It was in some ways a success, in others, not so much. The sauce I made was very close to something great. I like ginger a lot. I added a bit too much in this case: the curry powder was somewhat overpowered. On the other hand, much as I like cauliflower, in this application I found myself wanting a slab or pork or a chicken breast. There's something too insubstantial about a slab of cauliflower as a main course.Meanwhile, I'm a big fan of the Felicity Cloake take on pasta with mushrooms. The mirepoix adds some heft and complexity, and the porcini powder is genius. It's like an amplifier for the woody umami of the otherwise slightly flat chestnut mushrooms.
My feelings about the butternut squash gratin mirror my feelings about the confit chickpeas: delicious, though too light to be a standalone main. The gratin might work better with a bigger, chunkier salad than my delicate assemblage of arugula.For the week to come, I'll start with the sweet. Or perhaps sweets. Between the weather cooling down and my impending kitchen project, I've decided now is the moment to have another run at doing croissants. Unless there's a magical French bakery opening soon near me, DIY remains my best option with travel still restricted, and that door may soon close as well when my kitchen is torn apart.

âThose are a weekend breakfast treat, though. For a more dessert dessert, I'm going to try doing an olive oil cake. There's a lot of scope for noodling around. I like the idea of a confit orange and rosewater topping, though we'll have to see what my reserves of willpower are like.

Going savory, I need to deplete my giant stock of frozen fish. Something about the idea of a donburi appeals, so I'm thinking of doing a sushi rice bowl with salmon, probably blasted with heat under the grill in my oven.

As a veggie option, I'm taking inspiration from Frenchie and doing the heretical: making gnocchi (with mushrooms) as a veggie main course. Perhaps this proves that for all my forays into Italian cooking, I'm less an Italian at heart than someone who likes Italian food viewed through other culinary prisms. It will also give me another opportunity to riff on the excellent mushroom pasta from the last week.

Finally, I'm in the mood for a roast chicken, though I'm giving it a bit of a twist. As nonsensical as it feels, I want the warm (dare I say summery) heat of the Maghreb, so I'm planning to try doing a roast with harissa and a chili sauce. I'm suffering from squash overload after the gratin, though squash and harissa are also an excellent combination. I'll probably garnish the chicken with roast potatoes and perhaps some braised kale or sautéd spinach.

Per usual, I'd love to hear from you if you're enjoying this or have other ideas, and please feel free to share with your friends.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 32
Content:
Hello readers,

It hasn't quite sunk in yet, but my kitchen project is now well and truly underway. I'll keep writing about that from time to time on my mini-blog that I set up to chart its progress. As concerns this newsletter, my impression is that a lot of the timeline is going to be driven by how much money I want to spend on cabinets. If I go with pure Ikea, there's effectively zero wait time. At the other extreme of the price scale, if I go Poggenpohl it could be months before the cabinets make an appearance and can be installed. Apparently all the construction manufacturers are way behind due to the pandemic as well, only adding to the logistical challenges of getting a kitchen imported from Germany.

I may also have a brief hiatus around Christmas as my plans evolve. Though in the spirit of a cooking TV series, I may do a Christmas ideas special issue. Otherwise, I plan to keep this going until either construction or a huge public health improvement creates more of a change.

As for the week that's been, I once again overshot, and made more food than I thought I would. So I still haven't made the gnocchi. The croissants are in progress, though not quite ready for my self-imposed (and admittedly totally arbitrary) publication deadline. So a progress report there and the accompanying photos will have to wait for next week.The harissa-inflected roast chicken was very ho-hum. It has potential but needs work. Most notably, I should have ignored the recipe's suggestion and roasted closer to 450 °F than his 350 °F suggestion. There was a distinct lack of roast-ness.
Meanwhile, the miso salmon continues to be a winner. It's so simple, and so good. The donburi concept was also a good one, even if I found the Whole Foods own brand sushi rice a little disappointing. I want to blame Amazon, but I'm not sure Whole Foods was ever a great source for Japanese ingredients. Perhaps I will have to journey to an Asian supermarket and see if I can do better.
For the week to come, I'll start this week with the veggie option. After the last few attempts to do one big veggie main, I'm going to try and learn my lesson. The lovely people at Clover Food Lab continue to sell bags of their excellent pita, which feels very appropriate as a mezze foundation. I'll pair that with another Ottolenghi bean recipe, some roasted cauliflower, and (riffing on my Middle East-by-way-of-London theme) some grilled eggplant.

I'm also planning to draw down my still enormous supply of frozen fish, and do some salmon cakes. I still have some leftover katsu curry sauce that might add a nice bit of zing there. I tend to think of fish cakes as a starter rather than a main, but I'm looking for variety, and I think if they're paired with an interesting side, they'll be enough. I'm thinking of borrowing from one of my favorite dishes and serving these with lentils.

As I still need to go through the gnocchi, that's all I'm planning to do. For another idea, I'd suggest doing a pumpkin risotto. It's a great concept, even if most of the search results on Google completely ruin the concept. An actual eating pumpkin would be great. If not, butternut squash is also a good option. In any case, run away from anyone who suggests using a can of pumpkin purée.

For a sweet, I'm finally accepting that it's no longer the summer. This tahini cake with coffee caramel looks fantastic.

I'll end with the usual appeal. It's always fun to hear from you if you're enjoying this (or indeed if you have any less positive comments), and I'd encourage you to share with friends.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 33
Content:
Hello readers,

Without compromising my op-sec too much, I have booked some travel for the end of the year. Unless construction starts sooner — which I really doubt will happen at this point — the final 2020 installment of this newsletter will be either the weekend of the 6th or 13th of December, depending on my willpower to put together a Christmas edition. It should resume again in early January, by which time, who knows, perhaps we'll be back into a stricter lockdown and I won't even be able to have takeout lunches.

My latest attempt at croissants was definitely an improvement. I was a lot more rigorous about the precision of the slab of butter, and I decided to only do six at a time to make it easier to apply even pressure to the dough. But I'm still a long way off where I'd like to be. The lamination was a little bit uneven, and the croissants were a little bit misshapen.I've fallen so behind, the report on the DIY mezze and the very promising tahini caramel cake will have to wait for next week. I still haven't quite gotten the gnocchi right. It's a question of feel, I suspect. Less in the texture or flavor per se as much as getting each little pillow roughly the same size so they cook more evenly. This batch (or at least my attempts at capturing it with a camera) did not meet the quality level needed for inclusion here.

The salmon cakes were surpassingly good. They were a little generic, however. I'm not sure exactly what they need, but they definitely need something to give them a bit more zing and complexity.
Moving into the week to come, with the first (brief) hit of snow in the last few days, I'm beginning to really embrace the chillier weather. In that vein, I'm thinking of doing more of my favorite pasta and bean soup as a good lunch option. As ever, I'd highly recommend getting some really good beans. They're not all that expensive, and they make a huge difference.

Dinner-wise, I'm in the mood to do a low and slow braise. I have in mind something basic: chicken in red wine with aromatic vegetables. I do like to give it a twist and serve with polenta and separately roasted root vegetables, however. I'm also definitely not making a classic coq au vin, whatever the link may indicate. I like my braise lighter and to taste more of chicken, thyme, and red wine than smoked bacon.

As a veggie option — and going to a completely different part of the world where winter is perhaps less of a concept — I'm going to do a classic channa masala. Here again: get good dried chickpeas. I'll probably serve that with garlicky spinach and (of course) rice.

Much as a I want to continue depleting my seemingly endless supply of frozen salmon, I'm going to shift gears ever so slightly for the week to come, and instead do a white fish. Which one, I'm not entirely sure yet. If the food gods are with me, I'd get something like a nice striped bass. If not, I may have to settle for the more prosaic cod. In any event, I'll enrobe the gently roasted fish with a huge dollop of salsa verde. It's debatable how autumnal or winter it is, but I haven't done a nice salsa verde in at least a few months. People may think I'm a bottomless well of energy; in reality, now that I have literally recorded every home-cooked dinner for the last seven months, I honestly can't bring myself to look up the last time I did one.

For a sweet, I'm a little torn. Part of me wants to take another run at the olive oil cake concept. It was within striking distance of greatness. I managed to get my hands on some good blood oranges recently, and a blood orange confit appeals. On the other hand, I now have a ton of tahini, and there's only so much hummus I can eat. It's also very good in a chocolate chip cookie. We shall see.

It's always great to hear from people if you'd like to drop me a line, and feel free to share this with your friends.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 34
Content:
Hello readers,

I've deliberately avoiding turning this into a venue for my political musings, though I feel like I'd look crazy for not mentioning my pleasure at the election of Joe Biden. More importantly, though, I'm going to recommend (for the millionth time) Eitan Hersh's excellent book, Politics is for Power. I'm over the moon we've elected someone competent for the top job. But obsessing over national political races isn't going to drive anywhere near as much change — unless you're actually a political player — as focusing on people you can influence and building your ability to do so.

That out of the way, let's return to why (I hope) people read this.

My copy of the new Nigella Lawson book finally made its way to me from Blighty. I cannot recommend it highly enough. It's filled with the usual wit and witticism, with a few promising-looking recipes buried in between. Who else would compare celeriac to an albino coconut? I maintain my position that Nigella is not appreciated enough for her prose.
Moving right along, as it turns out, I forgot to buy cream for the coffee caramel-inflected tahini cake of two weeks ago. Especially as cases of COVID-19 continue to rise rapidly, I can't permit myself another trip for something so trivial. I wound up combining two ideas and pairing the tahini cake with a batch of confit blood orange peel instead. It's a good combination, even if I'm slightly dubious about the tahini really bringing anything to the preparation. When I've used all the peel, the leftover orange syrup is ripe for an appearance in a cocktail or on my signature Sunday morning pancakes.
The mini-mezze extravaganza was extremely adequate. Nothing about it blew my mind, yet it was hard to fault. Oil poaching butter beans is a great concept.On a more positive note, the grumpy fishmonger at Whole Foods notwithstanding, I was able to get my hands on some striped bass. A few minutes under the broiler and coated with salsa verde, it was a glorious thing.

The chicken braise hasn't quite happened yet, as is becoming a minor theme here. The weather decided to enter a freakish warm spell, undermining the coziness a nice red wine braise was meant to give. I also decided this was probably the last weekend to run outside without gobs of thermal clothing and biting wind until next year. As is my way, I slightly overdid it, which turned Saturday evening into more of a moan-and-recover-from-the-pain situation than my intended slow potter to braise some chicken in red wine.

I'll start with the sweet again for the week to come. My cant is to the gingerbread recipe in Cook, Eat, Repeat. It's filed away in the Christmas chapter of the book, and so I worry I'm jumping the gun. On the other hand, the last however many months have made time feel like a very loose concept.

For a veggie option, I'm returning to a classic and doing a nice pizza. I recommend the dough from one of my favorite pizza places. Seasonal? I don't know. But I definitely feel a lot less guilty blasting the oven when the warmth is welcome. The more straightforward nod to the season will be some combination of roasted vegetables, taking further advantage of all that heat.

I'm ready to return to the soy-lime seared tuna from another recent cookbook purchase, À la maison. My bottomless cache of frozen fish contains enough tuna that I need to use some of it up. Incidentally, for the avant-garde French-speaking cookbook enthusiast in your life, the same team has a new book, Cuites, available for preorder.

The seafood theme, such as it is, concludes with a prawn tagine. Once again, it's inspired by the excellent people at Honey & Co in London. The idea of adding cardamom in a savory dish is novel. Maybe it will be a disaster. I think it's worth trying at least once. My couscous supply has run out, and it remains mysteriously absent from store shelves, so I may have to serve this with rice.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you if you're enjoying this (or not!), and please feel free to forward and share. Writing this every week has really embedded itself in my "new normal," so I'll probably keep doing it no matter what for my own sanity. Not that having an audience isn't at least a little bit of an inducement.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 35
Content:
Hello readers,

Progress is slowly creeping along in my more meta project to renovate my kitchen. As it turns out, getting cabinets from one of the high-end German manufacturers is pretty expensive. In a couple of cases, breathtakingly so. In a couple of others, if I had a slightly more generous budget, I might have gone for them. As it stands, I think something flatpack is in my future.

Food-wise, the last week has been reasonably successful. I still wouldn't say I have the pizza process completely to my liking, but it's hardly disappointing. In the end, I paired the pizza with more of the Honey & Co tahini-crusted eggplant to use up my tahini crust material. I feel slightly guilty blasting the eggplant with so much heat it melts into nothing. On the other hand, the tahini crust really is delicious.
My second run at the seared tuna from Le Bristol was closer to what I'd like, though still not quite there. I need to get the pan even hotter. I'm also thinking the fish should be marinated before searing rather than after. The level of rareness was right. The uniform lukewarm temperature was not. I think it would be better if the outside were piping hot to contrast with the cool rare ruby interior.In the end, I couldn't get my hands on golden syrup to make the Nigella gingerbread. My sweet for the week was another run at the olive oil cake. This second attempt was better. There's nevertheless work to do. I want it to be moist, dense, and unctuous. What I made was still too airy and too dry.
The orange-cardamom-tomato shrimp dish has promise. I don't think I got the pan hot enough. It wasn't bad, so much as lacking in depth and intensity of flavor.

For the week ahead, I need to do a bit of a repeat. I still have lots of (delicious) salsa verde left in the refrigerator. Rather unoriginally, I'm going to get my hands on yet more fish that is not salmon, slide it under the grill, and cover in more salsa verde. It's simple, but always a good idea. In a nod to a more formal Italian meal, I'm thinking of doing that with a starter of spaghetti aglio e olio.

As a veggie option, I'm going to give this take on stuffed mushrooms a try. I'm inclined to think that the recipe ostensibly for two people will actually only serve me. At least that's what I'm planning to shop for. Worst case, I have leftovers to enjoy for lunch one afternoon.

Finally, I'm going to return to the Middle Easte-by-way-of-India biryani. I once again can't quite figure out whether it's seasonal because it comes from a part of the world that gets hotter and never quite gets as cold as New England or Western Europe. But, the spices are warming as the weather here finally beds down, and I love a one-pot meal from time to time.

I'm planning to do the chocolate chip cookies from the wonderful Mokonuts Bakery in Paris as a sweet. They don't quite have the cult-like following of somewhere like Levain Bakery, but frankly I think these are better as exotic-twist-on-a-classic cookies go.

Thanksgiving is coming up for we Americans. It's going to be a bit strange this year. I'm still not entirely sure what I'll wind up doing. Either way, I'm already thinking about new takes on classics to try. The idea of a cardamom pumpkin tart popped into my head the other day. As it turns out, that's a less original thought than I would've guessed.

In the meantime, I'd always love to hear from you, and would encourage you to share this with anyone who might be interested.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 36
Content:
Hello readers,

From a culinary point of view, the last week has been a dud, with maybe one exception.

Reading it, I didn't quite put together that the Nigel Slater "stuffed mushroom" dish was basically mushrooms stuffed with hummus. I like mushrooms. I like hummus. But it's not the most interesting meal. So unappealing was the dish that I used some of the mushrooms to make an impromptu mushroom pasta dish. Likewise, I found the veggie biryani somewhat underwhelming. I don't think there's anything fundamentally flawed about a veggie biryani, but this one did not bowl me over.
The one bright spot were the Mokonuts-style chocolate sesame cookies. I hadn't made them in ages, and they really do use a lot of sesame seeds. I had just enough. I'm going to have to restock. It was interesting to think about how much I spent on the ingredients for the cookies. I think it's possible that between the fancy single-origin chocolate and the fancy butter, the batch cost over $15. It's still a lot cheaper than buying designer cookies $4 a go, but it's slightly crazy to realize that.
The week ahead is a bit of a strange one for this newsletter. I'm still a little undecided on what I'm going to do for Thanksgiving. I'm definitely not traveling, but I feel like I have to do something at least a little special to commemorate. For anyone reading who's less on the fence food-wise, I'll take this first section to make a few suggestions.

If you're thinking of making a pumpkin pie, I'm going to float a radical idea: make it with actual squash. Not that I have anything per se against the canned pumpkin purée — I buy it all the time, for Thanksgiving and otherwise — but it's equally crazy to suggest it's as good as something that hasn't been blasted with pressure and heat as part of the canning process.

I've hosted Thanksgiving for 30 and for two. If you're afraid of doing a turkey, they're really not that hard. If you're not looking to feed 30 people, I don't think there's any shame in doing a roast chicken. Either way, I think it's essential to do mashed potatoes with a gravy. For the gravy in particular, there are really no excuses not to make it from scratch if you're roasting a whole bird. There are lots of very elaborate ways to do a superlative one. I think even something basic is pretty nice.

One tradition I'm not a fan of are stodgy overcooked vegetable dishes. Skip the green bean casserole or bizarre yam-marshmallow concoctions and opt for something with a whiff of Mediterranean something. I'd go for, say, braised squash with harissa. It will go just fine with the cranberry sauce.

Putting aside the vexed pandemic holiday planning, I have less vexed ideas for the rest of the week. For starters, with a bit of time off, I'm going to take another run at doing croissants. I still haven't quite mastered the technique, but I'm definitely getting better.

Keeping with the idle baking theme, I'm going to do some black bean burgers with — crucially — some DIY burger buns. I'll probably pair that with my favorite side: some oven-blasted slivers of sweet potato.

It's been ages and ages since I've done some mussels. If I can get fresh mussels, I'll probably be extraordinary boring and do something like a moules marinière. Though I think I'll pair that with some crusty bread rather than more fries. If not, maybe a seafood risotto.

Finally, assuming I don't wind up also doing chicken for Thanksgiving, I'm going to try out this Ottolenghi recipe for black pepper chicken. I'll probably serve that with rice and some pan-steamed tender stem broccoli.

Enjoy your Thanksgiving, however strange it may be this year, and as ever please feel free to pass this along.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 37
Content:
Hello readers,

For those interested in my renovation project, the process is creeping along. For the newsletter's purposes, it looks as though the biggest determinant of the program is the cabinet delivery time. That's going to take around three to four months, meaning I doubt work would start until the middle of winter. So there almost certainly will be a few installments of this in the new year.

For Thanksgiving I did a suitably scaled-down spread. There was a disastrous loaf of bread that was meant to be for stuffing. The roast chicken — there was no way I was going to do a whole turkey — actually turned out quite nicely. The biggest discovery was a run at another Ottolgenghi recipe, the harissa-tinted squash that I linked to last week. That was excellent: I'll definitely be making that again.

The moules marinière were a bit of a letdown. Fortunately, not due to my cooking. Rather, probably half the mussels the fishmonger gave me wound up being dead and therefore unsafe to eat. Not that I have too many complaints about making up the lost calories with more bread, but I do like mussels. Other than that, I've been coasting on leftovers. The black bean burgers will have to wait a bit.The croissants are an interesting story. I still haven't quite gotten them where I want them. But they keep getting better. In particular, this time I remembered to save (and freeze) my scraps from last time, so I had some "PF" (pâte fermetée) to toss in this batch. This appears to have improved the quality of my lamination. I didn't feel any of the butter poking through the dough and getting my hands greasy until the final step. And there, I suspect the issue was one of the dough not being relaxed enough: the longer it takes to roll out, the more time the butter has to soften. The easiest way to tell I struggled: most of the croissants only had five (rather than seven) segments. By the end, it was so hard to roll out, I had to stop before it got thin and big enough.
The week to come will be mostly a return to normal. Though there are some leftovers that still need using up. There are probably more creative or outright better ways I could use up the leftover chicken. But I find something strangely comforting about doing fajitas. That may or may not be related to quite how easy those are to throw together. Sometimes I do need a break from cooking.

Once again I'm going to turn to the reliable Yotam Ottolenghi for something to push my boundaries. I'm thinking of trying his recipe from this week for biangbiang noodles. Though I may tone it down a bit: I'm not sure I want to have my mouth numbed with chilis. That feels like it will go well with some seared broccoli.

For a shellfish fix, I'm going to turn back to the seafood risotto concept from last week. I'm not convinced mussel quality is a memoryless process, plus I'd like some variety. As the weather cools down more and winter begins really digging its heels in, I'm thinking of pairing that with some cavolo nero tossed with a bit of garlic and olive oil.

Finally, I'm going to do tuna carpaccio. I'm not entirely sure what I'll serve that with. It feels very summery, but I don't really want a tuna steak, and I really do have a lot of frozen tuna that I need to use. Quite possibly I'll have my stuffing reprieve, assuming I can successfully execute a loaf of bread again in the coming days.

I'll wrap all this up with some shortbread. It's completely incongruous with everything here, to be sure: it's neither Chinese nor Italian. But that's what I'm in the mood for. If I'm feeling motivated, I may try to give it a slightly more relevant twist. I feel like a dash of five spice or an anise-cardamom kick pushes it slightly more into the realm of Chinese cooking.

If you're enjoying this, I'd love to hear from you. I'd also encourage you to share this with friends who may enjoy it! Writing this is a strange new part of my pandemic routine, but I won't pretend that it's not at least a little motivating to have even this small audience.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Christmas 2020 Special
Content:
Hello readers,

I'm going to be taking a break from writing this newsletter for a few weeks. Exactly how long, I'm honestly too lazy to look at a calendar to figure out. It should be back sometime in January, however. Keep your eyes open for the usual delivery on one Sunday afternoon or another.

Before I sign off for the year, however, I thought I'd do a "holiday special" in the grand tradition of cooking TV series. I'll drop in a few links to food ideas, but I figured it might also be a nice idea to toss in a few gift ideas for the food enthusiast in your life.

Cookbooks

Ad Hoc at Home, Thomas Keller
I hesitate ever so slightly to recommend this. On the one hand, the recipes are great. This is a perfect "ambitious beginner" cookbook. Yes, the chicken and dumplings take forever to make. They are sublime. Nor can it be denied how big an impact Thomas Keller has had on food in the US. On the other, I feel like he's sold out a little bit in the last 10 years. Slapping your name on the catering service on a mass-market cruise line smacks of rent seeking.

How to Eat, Nigella Lawson
Her first and possibly still best cookbook. Though I don't know it really should even be called a "cookbook." It's more a memoir with some recipes. Of course, that's not why you buy it: you buy it for the luscious prose.
Cook, Eat, Repeat, Nigella Lawson
Her latest cookbook. It's much more like How to Eat than previous more cookbook-like cookbooks. It's a joy to read.

The River Cafe Cookbook, Ruth Rodgers and Rose Gray
This has become the cookbook I turn to more than any other. It's astonishing that this was published in 1995. Nothing about it is dated. Every recipe is a joy. If I had to pick one cookbook to use for the rest of my life, this might well be it.

À la maison, Victoire Loup
Yes, this is written in French. If you happen to know someone who can decipher it, it's a blast. The 60 recipes come from home kitchens of everyone from chefs running restaurants with three Michelin stars to the best spots to pick up a cookie in Paris.

Vietnamese Home Cooking, Charles Phan
Phan is responsible for one of my favorite restaurants, The Slanted Door. This book is a lot more accessible than the Slanted Door book: it's food to make at home.

The Elements of Pizza, Ken Forkish
His pizza restaurant is a family favorite. While you're never going to be able to make a true Neapolitan-style pizza at home without a very fancy oven, this book will get you close, and shows off a whole variety of other pizza techniques.

Food Products

Really good dried pasta
Look for something like Afeltra or Monograno. It will cost more than the basic stuff at a supermarket, but as a treat to give someone as a gift, it's worth every penny. You'll be able to tell the difference.

Single-origin chocolate
That is, chocolate made from cocoa beans from one place. Like a vintage wine. My favorite producer is Pump Street, out of the UK. There are a few good US producers too, such as Dandelion out of San Francisco.
Fun spice blends
I like Curio Spice (here in Boston) or La Boîte (out of New York). Their spice blends are not your usual generic paprika-heavy chicken rub: think seaweed salt or fennel-citrus fleur de sel.

Small estate tea
I had to get in a plug here for my favorite tea shop: Postcard Teas, in London. Everything they sell is great, and comes from tea estates that are smaller than 25 acres.

Eat and Drink

The Christmas and New Year celebrations themselves aren't times I do a ton of cooking. I chip in, but spend more time as the person responsible for filling in all the more prosaic meals in between. For that reason, I don't have a handy go-to set of Christmas dishes.

But there are a few quasi-traditions that I find myself thinking of, mostly sweets. While members of my family still use a recipe from the 1960s and an extruding press with tree-shaped inserts, I'm going to encourage you to make spritzgebäck biscuits with a piping bag. For Christmas morning, I'm often drafted in to make cinnamon buns.

I also love a good panettone. These are increasingly easy to find — my local Whole Foods stacks them floor to ceiling — if you want to buy one, and I would very much understand if you do. But they're actually not all that hard to make.
On the Japanese side of my family, we (at least in non-pandemic years) take the New Year celebration very seriously food-wise. I won't link to a recipe, but mochi is a must-have. For as long as I can remember, we've been making it from scratch using a futuristic imported machine. It's not quite the same when it's not fresh.

If you're more exciting than I am, you might be looking for something to toast in the new year. I'm going to recommend you search out a champagne or crémant that's "brut nature" or "brut zéro." That is, a sparkling wine with no sugar added (no dosage) for the yeast to consume and generate the bubbles. These are bone dry and delicious.

This year will not have a ton of holiday parties, of course. If you want to pretend, I love doing gougères (savory choux pastry buns with cheese) for an hors d'œuvre. The same technique for making choux dough can also be used, in its sweet variation, to do another great party snack: little chouquettes made with pearl sugar.

I hope at least one or two people have found this useful. As usual, feel free to forward this to friends, and I'd love your feedback.

Until next year,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 38
Content:
Hello readers,

This will be the last official edition for 2020. It's a strange feeling that the year is almost over. A lot has happened, and yet it feels like I've been cheated out of a year that could have been. Fear not, however: next week I've got an extra-long Christmas special ready to go.

The week that's been has been a mixed bag, due mostly to my own lack of energy. I couldn't rouse myself to go to the trouble of making biangbiang noodles from scratch in the end.

My risotto of questionable seasonal congruency was its usual comforting self. It was greatly helped by a batch of chicken stock made with the remnants of my Thanksgiving mini-feast the week before. I've probably already said it before: using really good stock makes a huge difference. I'm sure there are better brands of broth in a box. I doubt whether even the best is as good as even the most clumsily prepared stock that's not made with assorted flavor enhancers and scant quantities of identifiable food.
I haven't had a chance to do the tuna carpaccio, so it won't make the photo deadline. This is due mostly to my perpetual lack of foresight. Every time I realized it was tuna day, I had forgotten to move the tuna from the freezer to the refrigerator the night before. Usually I can work around this oversight by effecting a more rapid thaw in changes of cold water. That won't work if I want to carpaccio-ify the fish and eat it raw.

The shortbread will also miss the photo deadline. Once I finished the leftover Thanksgiving sweets, I realized I was making olive oil biscuits for another activity, and two sweets at the same time was too much. But it will happen. I can't explain why, but I am desperate for some shortbread.

For the week ahead, I'm going to turn my hand back to the carrot blueberry muffins. I remain convinced I can reverse engineer the reference product with a few more attempts. This is all the more urgent because my usual source has phased out the blueberry for an inferior "seasonal" pumpkin number.

Around this time last year I was meandering around Paris, disrupted by a once-in-a-generation transit strike rather than a global pandemic. Something about that has put me in mind of a classic dish of some stripe. I'm still rolling around ideas in my head. My inclination is to something like a simple pan-roasted chicken breast with a chicken glace. If I were in a serious French restaurant, they'd probably serve that with a very fancy starter. A pumpkin velouté would be nice. I'm not sure I can muster the energy to find and prepare an eating pumpkin.I'm in the mood for a polenta-mushroom combination for the week's veggie option. My local Whole Foods had some promising wild mushrooms in last week. That might go well with more braised kale of some description. The only snag is that I'm out of polenta, and on my last visit the friendly neighborhood Eataly only had the questionable quick-cook variety that I find always clumps.

Finally, I need to continue working through my supplies of frozen fish. I've used up all the salmon and I don't particularly want to repeat tuna, which leaves the striped bass left to use. This I'm planning to keep simple. It's hard to do better than a nice blast of heat under the grill, a squeeze of citrus, and a herby sauce of some description. I'll probably do that with some haricots verts tossed in a bit of good olive oil.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you if you're enjoying the newsletter. Please feel free to share it with others!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 39
Content:
Hello readers,

A lot has happened since I last wrote. I travelled for the first time since March 2020, I had a coronavirus test for the first time, and armed insurrectionists tried to overthrow the government. But I'm now back, and hopefully some order will soon be restored to the world.

There is still no firm start date for my kitchen renovation. My best guess is that the newsletter will continue through the rest of the winter, and work may begin near the end of March.

The past week has been an especially strange one, even in my own little bubble. Living in Massachusetts, I was required to quarantine for two weeks, or until I was able to produce a negative coronavirus test. As it turns out, getting a test is much more difficult than it ought to be, so I've been stuck in my apartment since I got back from Christmas on the West Coast.

I've been eating a lot of delivery by consequence. It's amazing to think there are people who sustain themselves this way. It's incredibly expensive! And I say that as someone who doesn't bat an eye at spending $30 for a pound of peak-season king salmon. I've been fairly pragmatic: there's not a lot of interest to report there.

Turning to the week to come, I'll begin the week with yet more delivery and whatever I'm able to cobble together from the store cupboard. Assuming — I think it's a safe bet — my coronavirus test comes back negative reasonably soon, then I can begin getting back into the swing of things.

For obvious reasons I wasn't able to sample any of the fun restaurants in Portland this Christmas. But the highly abbreviated New Year feast this year has inspired me to explore Japanese food more than I already have.

Like the French food culture, the Japanese love to take ideas from other places and mess around with them. In that direction, I'm going to try a dish from chuka ryori, or the Japanese subgenre of dishes stolen from the Chinese and adapted to local tastes. Specifically, I like the look of this Japanese-style mapo tofu. I'm also planning to do this as my veggie option for the week by substituting the ground pork for a mushroom duxelles.

Moving to a different part of Asia, I'm going to repeat an old favorite, the Slanted Door lemongrass chicken. The Asian grocery should have good fresh lemongrass, and something about being at least on the same side of the country as the Slanted Door gave me a hankering for their lemongrass chicken. To go with, I'll make more of the fire-kissed baby bok choi that I first made last year after reading about wok hei at home in Kenji Lopez-Alt's Times column.

Finally, I still have some amazing Rancho Gordo black beans to use up. I was tempted to do another black bean soup. Instead, I'm going to do something close: a black bean and sweet potato chili. It also gives me a chance to use up some of the chilis in adobo and dried peppers I've had sitting around for ages. If I'm feeling underworked, I may try to toss together some cornbread to go along with.
As sweets go, I need at least a few weeks with no cookies, biscuits, or chocolate. Though at least I did get some excellent, excellent Grasmere gingerbread over Christmas. The winter, however, means that most fresh fruit isn't really a great option. To that end, I'll probably wind up doing something simple with frozen peak-season fruit, like a blueberry crumble.

I'll be back next week with more to say, and the photo series should return, too. Is there anything you're interested in exploring in the new year? I'd love to hear from you! And as ever, while I now think of this as a very public way to do meal planning, I do continue at least in part because people read it. If there's anyone you know who you think would enjoy, feel free to forward.

Until then,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 40
Content:
Hello readers,

I'm still settling back into the groove of writing this every week. Mostly in terms of getting the quantities right so I wind up not eating leftovers for many days in a row. A long winded way, in other words, of saying that I didn't get around to making everything I'd planned.

The rise of new coronavirus variants is also making me rethink even my weekly in-person shopping trips. Part of me is definitely afraid that I won't have as much control over what I get. More than that, there's something about grocery delivery that feels too decadent. I read somewhere that, even before the pandemic, the share of households with domestic help is at its highest levels since the Gilded Age peak in the late 19th and early 20th century, probably in large part because of people like me. I'm not sure that's something to be proud of.

Returning to what I did get around to, the black bean-sweet potato chili was pretty good. Either the recipe or my execution of it needs some work, however. Possibly both. My biggest complaint was the inclusion of beer. It definitely peps up the recipe. The chili is better for its addition. Either I didn't cook it down enough or there was too much of it, though. The beer dominated rather than lending that bit of background complexity. Also not the most photogenic meal.
The lemongrass chicken was its usual successful self. Unlike many other products, fresh lemongrass is not cheaper at H-Mart than it is at Whole Foods. I would contend that the quality is a bit better.

Contemplating the week to come, I still have to actually begin my dive into new Japanese dishes, beginning with last week's Japanese-style mapo tofu. Let's just say I made too much chili and too much lemongrass chicken.

In typical fashion, I'm going to try out another recipe from Yotam Ottolenghi's Guardian column. This preparation of miso peanut butter chickpea salad looks excellent. I've become increasingly bored with what most people think of as a "salad" — some kind of dainty lettuce with a few chopped vegetables tossed in and maybe a vinaigrette. These chunkier more adventurous ones are much better for my money. As it's freezing outside, I'll probably pair that with something hot, maybe a simple rice noodle stir fry-type concoction.

Last, I'm going to try out this somewhat more experimental way to use up more of my recently replenished stock of frozen salmon. I'm hoping that the kombu cure in this preparation will add a little extra zing. I'm not sure how "traditional" this is, but it also definitely has a Japanese cant.

For a sweet, I'm going to throw together some Anzac biscuits. On some level, I feel like these aren't seasonal only insofar as Anzac Day is in April. On another, they're so good I don't really feel like I need an excuse. This wasn't a particularly inspired choice. Despite my Christmas cookie hangover, I can't get excited about fruit desserts in the dead of winter. I found this by more or less flipping through a cookbook.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you and please feel free to share with friends!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 41
Content:
Hej læsere,

From a completion perspective, this is my first successful week in the new year. From a food satisfaction perspective, it was more of a mixed bag.

The Japanese-vegetarian mapo tofu was very middling. I slightly wonder if the Japanese variant I tried had some of the edges rounded off. The biggest problem was easily remedied by adding more shoyu. The recipe as written was a little under-seasoned. It's also not the most photogenic dish, or is at least well beyond my food styling skills.In the end, I wound up throwing together some drunken noodles to go along with the chickpea salad. The salad is excellent even if I'd make some tweaks next time. I'm unconvinced the chickpeas needed to be roasted. Or at least that all of the chickpeas needed to be roasted. The peanuts and raw vegetables give a nice crunch. Some creamy chickpeas would've been nice to contrast. It was also a mistake to use the miso I had — a very full-bodied red variety — which made everything a shade too salty. Drunken noodles are difficult to really mangle. They're an excellent excuse for another hit of cilantro.The kombu-cured salmon really didn't seem worth it to me. Frankly, it seemed like an inferior version of the miso-marinated variety that I picked up at the beginning to this strange project from the late Taku Sekine.

For next week, I'm going to have a run at this hamachi bowl that I found while trying to find a recipe for the Japanese-inflected mapo tofu. I still have lots of frozen tuna in my freezer that needs using, and this looks tasty. I'm eating far more rice than I would typically; perhaps that's the inevitable consequence of eating more Japanese food.

The wind is howling outside, and the draft at my desk is stronger than usual. I'm in the mood for something warm and warming. Something like this quick fish soup should be relatively easy to toss together. If I'm feeling especially energetic, that would sit nicely with some braised kale.

For a veggie option — and at the risk of seeming exceedingly dull — I'm going to do yet another soup. Maybe I can't quite shake the need to put protein at the center of the meal. Possibly this is a better-justified requirement that I eat more than grains and vegetables. Whatever the case, if I'm doing a veggie main I always feel like I have to use something like chickpeas or mushrooms, which, for reasons that I can't quite put my finger on, I'm slightly sick of as I think about the week ahead. Thus soup. Thus soup with beans.

My initial thought was a borlotti-cavolo nero soup from a cookbook I was flipping through. Then I realized I don't have quite enough borlotti beans left, Rancho Gordo is still out of everything, and I've yet to find someone local selling dried borlotti beans worth buying. Thus more black bean soup.

The Nordic countries are good at winter, I feel like. For this week's sweet I'm going to try doing some pebernødder from the people of Denmark. They're a little out of season: my understanding is that they're more typically eaten at Christmas. But I like the idea of something (relatively) light with a hit of spice and, if I understand the concept correctly, a bit of crunch.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you, and please feel free to share this with friends!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 42
Content:
Hello readers,

For better or worse, I've settled back into an "I can't go anywhere" routine. The kitchen project continues to inch along — it too is suffering pandemic slowdowns — and it looks like I'll have a functional kitchen for the whole winter. On the plus side, that might mean it will be a bit less onerous to get more interesting takeout during the project.
Beginning with the biggest success, like their design and their language, the Danes are onto something beautiful in their simplicity in the pebernødder. There's room to improve the uniformity of them at the shaping stage, but that's about all I can complain about. They're wonderful and very easy to do.
The rest was fairly unremarkable to my eyes. The marinated tuna was very adequate. It would've been better if I'd hunted down some yellowtail, but I really do need to use up my supply of frozen tuna.
