The black bean soup was as good as usual. Perhaps slightly improved with the exotic heirloom beans I used. Likewise, the fish soup was a nice balm for the incredibly cold weather we're having here this weekend. It's an Italian dish, but the addition of ginger really does pep it up.

I'm putting a brief pause on my Japanese project. Largely this is because I'm lazier than people imagine. I have it in my head to make something with udon or soba as my next Japanese dish. My local Whole Foods — even before the regrettable Amazon takeover — has never had good Japanese noodles. The best option is somewhat inconvenient when you combine freezing temperatures with a desire not to use public transport or ride in a car with another person. I'll return to this theme once I can get my hands on some noodles without compromises.

Back we go, then, to something more Western. I'm in the mood for the tomato-ginger cod from Brasserie Lazare. (A quick reminder the recipes I link to are not necessarily the recipe that I'm cooking.) Yes, fine, it's in many ways quite similar to the fish soup that I made last week. I have a whole bunch of ginger left to use, and it's freezing outside. I'd like to think this, at least in the spirit of the original, will be a bit more refined.

For a veggie option, I'm going to do a mushroom stroganoff in the same line of thinking. It's freezing, it's winter, it's bleak (in more ways than one), and a stroganoff is a winter classic. I'm not sure I agree with the Jamie Oliver stroganoff-rice combination, but neither am I optimistic about finding good egg noodles. The stroganoff may have to go over basmati rather than something slippery.

Finally, I'm going to have a stab at another Ottolenghi recipe in the same it's-freezing-I-want-something-warming theme: a lentil and eggplant stew. I'm saving my Puy lentils for another time, at least until supplies become more available again, so I'm going to find out if the possibly even fancier black caviar lentils I have kicking around will do the job.

There's a part of me that wants to make something incredibly gooey and rich, like Nigella Lawson's wonderful cheeky emergency brownies. As I play the image of eating that through my mind's eye, I can't help anticipating that slightly ugly feeling of sugar rush. Instead, I'm going to have another try at an olive oil cake. I'm in the mood for a hit of citrus.

If you're enjoying this, I'd love to hear from you and of course feel free to forward to friends.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 43
Content:
Hej læsere,

This week I have truly internalized the lesson that even a mass of grey-brown looks photogenic enough to share with a sprinkle of green.

My memory of the lemon ginger cod from Saint Lazare was fuzzier than I thought. Whether I did justice to their version of the dish, I no longer feel qualified to judge. Either way, I was pretty happy with what I threw together. The ginger really does add a certain something, and my improvised lemon-thyme compound butter was very nice indeed.
The mushroom stroganoff I've done before. As more of a gin person, I don't tend to keep lots of whiskey around. The stroganoff was the worse for it. That hit of oaky smokiness and the flambé would have added some needed complexity, even if it was still otherwise pretty good.
I was reasonably happy with the lentil-eggplant stew. It could have been a bit more stew-like. In the sense that there wasn't that wonderful thick gravy I associate with something like a short rib braise. If I had to guess, this was my fault: I added additional water until it seemed like there was vaguely enough, which probably wound up being too much.I tried a new recipe for the olive oil cake with my own preemptive modifications. I was pretty pleased with the result. It was much denser and gooier while still being wonderfully moist and without being cloying. It's difficult to describe.Changing gears to next week, I'm going all-in with more beige food in the form of a fish pie. I've expressed my relatively newfound admiration for the British-style mash-on-stew format in previous editions. This isn't an especially challenging dish either for my palette or my technical abilities. Next week promises more very cold weather, however. This is the balm I want.

More on the challenging and experimental end, a pan-fried mackerel and citrus salad. I've also mentioned my increasing indifference for standard "salads" recently. This citrus number — meant to be more savory than sweet, it goes without saying — is another nod in that direction. I'm less optimistic that mackerel will be possible to find. Something less characterful (but available) may have to substitute.

For a veggie option, it's more lentils. As more of a countercyclical injection of vividness, I'm going to try this red lentil coconut curry. I suppose citrus, here in the form of lime, is in season, so perhaps this is winter-appropriate after all.

As a sweet, I'm still working my way through the olive oil cake. If I feel the need for more, I'm inclined to reach for the pebernødder again. They're that easy, that good, and have a name that's fun to say.

I'd still love to hear from you if you're enjoying this, and, of course, please feel free to share with friends.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 44
Content:
Hello readers,

The past week has been reasonably successful from a food perspective. Though I once again didn't quite get the quantities right. The fish pie will have to wait for the week to come. On the plus side, the weather is still cold enough that I don't feel like I've missed my comfort food window.
Unsurprisingly, I wasn't able to get my hands on any mackerel. The citrus salad, though, was very nice. It's definitely in the mold of non-boring-piles-of-lettuce salads. I've really become a fan of blood oranges — normal oranges are too sweet! — and putting them in a savory salad is a great idea.
For the second time, I can't recommend pebernødder enough. They're so easy and so good. It also gives me pleasure that the word for butter in Danish is smør (like smear), as if the only spread worth knowing about is butter.
When I pulled the recipe for the lentil dal, I liked the sound of the combination of flavors. I hadn't quite read it thoroughly enough, however. It also turns out to be incredibly simple to throw together. A sort of one-dish meal. You can taste the shortcuts to some degree, but I think it works. Certainly relative to the level of effort, it's a great return on the time invested.

For the week ahead, I remain in the mood for things warm and rich.

As mentioned at the beginning, I still need to do the fish pie. I'm having to slightly tweak mine because apparently my local Whole Foods did not have hot smoked white fish, and hot smoked salmon is surprisingly expensive. The suggested 350 grams would've run almost $20!

I have a bunch of celery and some slightly sad carrots that need using up. To that end, my veggie dish of the week will be another Felicty Cloake recipe. Her pasta ai funghi is excellent, mostly thanks to the masterstroke of adding some pulverized porcini mushrooms as a flavor supercharger.

The pandemic and the weather continue to frustrate my effort to make more Japanese food. This weather would be perfect for ramen or udon. I'm too cheap to have it delivered from a restaurant, by the time I walk it home it's cold, and I can't get good noodles at the local Whole Foods. (This one I'm not blaming on Uncle Jeff; the local branches of Whole Foods have never had good Japanese noodles.)

In its stead, I'm going to do a poulet à la moutarde, which is a fancy way of saying chicken braised in a mustard and white wine. It's actually quite simple to throw together, and will help me use up the bottle of wine I need to open for the fish pie. If I can get my hands on good polenta to replenish my stock, I'll swap that in for potatoes for some variety.

For something sweet, I'm going to take another run at PLF and do more croissants next weekend. I have the time, it goes without saying, and a top-class French bakery has yet to replace one of the empty storefronts in my neighborhood.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you and please share with friends!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 45
Content:
Hello readers,

We are edging perilously close to the one year mark on this project. Current trends suggest this will keep going well past the 52nd edition, but we shall see.

This sad milestone is not helped by the continuing fallout of the pandemic in other ways. After over two months of going back and forth with the manufacturer, my kitchen cabinets are finally ordered and paid for. The bad news: delivery times have slipped again to 14-18 weeks. At this point, it may also wind up taking a year from engaging my architects to final delivery on what is a pretty small project.

Back to food, the fish pie wound up working pretty well. At some point I am going to have to find someone who can sell me smoked haddock. Hot smoked salmon is great, but it's kind of boring to have salmon-on-salmon in a fish pie.

The Felicity Cloake mushroom pasta continues to be a favorite. Though this time I used a wider noodle than my first attempt. Next time I have to find (or make) tagliatelle. The fettuccine was better than whatever noodle I used last time, but it still felt undersized.
In the end, I decided to make bread (to go with the chicken) instead of the croissants. Perhaps the lesson there is that I should try to drum up more motivation. For some reason I have no problem going through the crazy steps to make PLF, but hand washing the bowl of my stand mixer is a bridge too far. The chicken was somewhat unremarkable. A good way to use up a bottle of wine, if nothing else.Looking forward, I find myself craving the chickpea salad that I tried out a few weeks ago. With one attempt behind me, I'll have a chance to give this the tweaks I think it needs, like not roasting all the marinated chickpeas in the oven for more textural contrast. I'm thinking of pairing that with something like these cod cakes.

The weather looks to be getting a bit more tolerable in the next couple of weeks, so hopefully I can resume my forays into Japanese cooking soon.

At the opposite end of that spectrum, my quest for variety has pushed me into really wanting a hamburger. It gives me another opportunity to use the excellent burger bun recipe from my favorite YouTube channel. I'm also going to be a horrible snob and get some of those excellent Impossible Foods faux burgers, which, for a weeknight dinner, are convincing enough for me. That might work with leftover chickpea salad, or if not that then some quick shoestring fries.

Technically that might be a veggie option, but it doesn't really feel in the spirit of it. For that, I'll go back to the excellent veggie chili that I made nearer the beginning of this project. I have a ton of lesser dried beans that I bought for that explicitly that have been sitting around unused.

In lieu of a sweet, I'm going to try this savory bread recipe from the excellent people at Honey & Co. I feel like it doesn't culturally go with anything, but that's nothing to stop it from working well in a madcap fusion sort of way.

I'd still love to hear from you if you're enjoying this, and I'd love for you to share it, too.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 46
Content:
Hello readers,

I'm not entirely sure what happened, but I've once again done some bad planning. In the sense that I still haven't made the chili or done the burger night because I've had too much else to get through.
But I did crank out some more home-size baguettes — very tasty for breakfasts — and got around to the cod cakes and the second iteration of the chickpea miso salad. The cod cakes lacked cohesion: they fell apart during cooking. This may be my strange Schrödinger's cheapness coming through again. Rather than buy a box of (very inexpensive) saltine crackers, I used rather posher water crackers that I already had at home. Likewise, due to pandemic restrictions, good olives were only available in pre-portioned containers. I couldn't bring myself to spend $15 on many times more kalamata olives than I actually needed for the bread.
I'm tossing in a photo of a grilled leek from two weeks ago for non-directed visual interest. It hasn't been a very photogenic week.

Going into next week, I did bake off the burger buns, so they're at least ready to go. The tangzhong technique really does work well for making super soft buns at home.

I'll actually bother to get around to doing the excellent veggie chili that I was supposed to do this past week. In the spirit of making this newsletter more interesting, I'd really like to do some cornbread to go with. I'm having a surprisingly hard time getting my hands on good polenta, however, so it may not happen. Either way, I will confess to having a preference for southern cornbread, despite being a devoted northerner in most matters.

It's been a few weeks since I've dug into my pandemic stock of frozen fish, so this week I'll repeat the classic grilled salmon with salsa verde. I feel like I owe people reading this at least one slightly novel item, so instead of whatever else, I'll serve that with a farro and roasted red pepper salad that feels at least somewhat seasonally appropriate. We are inching closer to spring, but aren't quite there yet.

For a sweet, I'm going more weekend breakfast this week. For the longest time I've done pancakes for breakfast on weekends. I don't know why or how that happened, but there we are. I've recently started swapping out the crème fraîche for tahini, which has been a nice change. It has to be said that even once a week, pancakes can still become repetitive. This time, I'm going to toss together some cinnamon buns. Or maybe swap out the cinnamon for cardamom and continue my slightly inexplicable exploration of Danish food.

Once again, I'd love to hear from you if you're enjoying this (or not!), and please share with friends!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 47
Content:
Hello readers,

While we're still about a month out from the 52nd edition — the official one year mark — this is the one year anniversary of my pandemic confinement. It's difficult to imagine that a year ago I had just returned from a vacation on another continent.

Last week I put all my plans right. I did non-burger burger night and I did the chili. The burgers, while tasty, didn't make the photo cut. The chili was excellent, though either I misremembered the level of heat intensity or I got unlucky with the chipotle I used this time. It wasn't so spicy as to be inedible, but I would've liked it a few shades softer.
The cardamom buns were another minimalist Danish success. They're incredibly easy. I usually cut the quantity of sugar recipes suggest. In this case, it felt like an error. The buns were almost a little too dull. Maybe I need to embrace the true Danish path and slather them with even more butter. (I really love that in Danish, butter is smør, like "smear," as if there is nothing else you'd ever want to slather onto a slice of bread.)
The Italian-inflected salmon with farro salad was great. I forgot to buy basil for the salsa verde and wound up buying too little parsley for a full batch. It was still pretty good, and it's admittedly hard to tell it was a one-note sauce herb-wise. Still, I'm convinced I could taste the difference. The farro salad I got more spot-on, and would highly recommend. I'll admit I'm not the world's greatest fan of feta, so skipped that. Not that roasting red peppers is really that hard, I did cheat a bit by using some excellent (leftover) roasted red peppers from a jar.

Next week, I'm going to continue swapping dessert-desserts with interesting breakfast options. If not novel, I'm going to really, seriously do croissants next weekend. My big problem is always forgetting to make the initial dough on Friday night. I really don't have anything that exhausting to do, and yet on Friday night I struggle to find the energy to make the dough to encase the butter.

If the forecast is to be believed, we'll get a brief respite from the winter weather this week. I'm going to attempt to ease my way in with this salt and pepper fish recipe that I found while poking around online.

It's also going to be very cold the rest of the week, which means I feel less guilty about blasting my oven to do pizza. I'm too lazy to look up when I last did this. It was at least a little while ago, so I don't feel like I'm really repeating myself. If I'm feeling motivated, I may branch out from the traditional mozzarella-basil-tomato trio and do mushroom-pesto. Either way, I'll pair that with roasted carrots to take full advantage of the super hot oven.

For my more overtly veggie option, I'm going to do another Ottolenghi recipe: roasted sweet potatoes with maple and pecans. It needs something to go with it. I'm really tempted to go all-in and serve it with rice and pita. I should probably do something slightly more measured. Maybe I'll roast off some cauliflower.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you. Have you learned anything from this over the past year? Eventually I'll be allowed out again. I'm trying to figure out how this will evolve now that it's become embedded in my weekly routine. And, of course, please forward this to your friends if you're enjoying it. I do this primarily for myself, but especially for the (admittedly minimal) effort I put into the photos, it's nice to know someone's seeing them.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 48
Content:
Hello readers,

Another week, and I'm behind again. Professional bakers like to save the trimmings from their pastry to kickstart a new batch of dough. It minimizes food waste and the fermentation happening in the dough adds extra flavor. As I don't make (say) croissants from scratch every day, I usually freeze these leftovers until the next batch. So, while I did remember to make the croissant dough on Saturday night, I did not remember to take the PF (pâte fermentée) out of the freezer on Friday night to thaw.

I'm going to tempt fate and make the croissants all in a single day. But that day is today, so the jury is still out on the result.
The rest was good. The salt and pepper fish was nice. Next time I'm going to use a firmer fish — monkfish would be excellent — and an uncoated pan I can get hotter. There wasn't as much browning as I wanted, and cod doesn't really hold its shape.
One of my lunch places had a great mushroom sandwich on the menu, so I kept it rather boring and stuck to mozzarella and basil for the pizza. I do really get a kick out of purple carrots. They're the same price, too, so  why not?

The sweet potato main has yet to happen. At the very least, I know I have all the ingredients.

Looking forward, the weather has settled back into a less unsettling early spring pattern. It's a tenuous link to be sure, but I'm responding to it with comfort food in the form of enchiladas. I'm hoping someday the drug cartel problem improves (or I become vastly more Mexican street smart, which is probably even less likely), and I could safely visit a bunch of random tiny villages to really understand how the enchilada fits into the food culture. Until then, I will remain concerned that I'm doing a disservice to people.

For the (overtly) veggie option, I'm going to try out this recipe for aubergine (eggplant) shawarma from the always excellent people at Honey & Co in London. (The fact they're one of the two regular contributors to the FT's food section makes me really feel at home with that as my primary international newspaper. Highly recommend.) I may not be able to get world-class baguettes here, but the fine people of Clover do a mean pita bread to go with.

My salsa verde from a bit ago is languishing in my refrigerator. It's a vicious cycle: I make it to use up leftover parsley and basil — you have to buy so much — then I have too much salsa verde. At least it keeps much longer. So it's back to my mini River Cafe for one: some kind of roasted fish, some kind of roasted vegetable, maybe a bit of farro salad as a starter.

For a sweet, I'm planning to solve two problems at the same time by doing sourdough discard brownies. Between the cardamom buns and the pizza, I haven't felt like there was a good justification for making more bread. Which has meant my sourdough starter discard has gone straight in the bin, to keep it healthy. This is more indulgent than my usual sweet. At least it's for a good cause.

As ever, I'd love to hear from you, and please share!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 49
Content:
Hello readers,

Another week, though still very little to report. The weather does appear to have turned enough that I may visit a restaurant soon for some outdoor dining. Sadly, a number of favorite places have crossed the point of no return. Though I'm also hoping that there will be a bit of renewal with lower rents and simply more space for new ideas to grow.

Returning to the last week, on the one hand, I did make the croissants. On the other hand, it was a bit of a disaster. When it finally came time to make the croissants, I realized I only had oat milk. Such is my dedication, I forged ahead regardless. I haven't taken any measurements, but it's as if oat milk is drier than real dairy. Beyond the point of no return I realized the dough was too wet and too tough. The croissants were correspondingly too dense.
The enchiladas were good, if unremarkable. I remain concerned that I'm more Emily in Paris than Elegance of the Hedgehog in my level of cultural sophistication here. Likewise, I don't know I have much to say about my latest adventure in roasted fish with salsa verde.
The eggplant shwarma was more interesting. The concept is great. Between the recipe itself and my execution, it needs some work. Everything was under seasoned, and my homespun ras el hanout was too warm and not savory enough. The flavor was more eggplant nothingness than the salty earthy tang of good shwarma. I'm thinking the addition of miso somewhere wouldn't go amiss. The other problem is deeper. Especially crammed into high-quality pita, it reminded me too much of the lunches I pick up from the people at Clover two or three times a week. Dinner needs to be more sacred.
The brownies were fine in an unremarkable way. It's difficult not to enjoy eating something that's mostly made of chocolate, sugar, and butter. I suppose I was disappointed that more of the acid tang from the levain didn't come through.
Moving along to next week, I feel as though spring has finally arrived.

I'll dive back in with a seafood paella. I've made peace with paella at home in the same way I've made peace with pizza at home. I'm never going to have a home oven that goes to 500 °C in the same way it will never be practical for me to own a three-foot paella pan and dig a fire pit. But with a little scientific thinking — mainly, only do paella for one or two people at home — it's possible to get good results.

As my overtly veggie option, I'm going to have a stab at doing more bao, inspired by this series from Kenji Lopez-Alt at Serious Eats. I'm not sure I have the willpower to do any deep frying, but I ought to be able to take some inspiration from his ideas.

While it's warmer, it's difficult to say it's actively warm. So I don't feel at all guilty taking the opportunity next weekend to try making ramen from scratch. I'll probably go veggie here — I really love the earthiness-on-earthiness of miso with mushroom — and will definitely pair the noodles with an interesting salad-y dish on the side.

Sweet-wise, I need something to contrast with the last week's incredibly indulgent brownies. It's very possible I may not even do something sweet this week. Though if I do, it will likely be something else I can tell myself is appropriate for breakfast, like this babka on my favorite YouTube channel.

Last but not least, Easter is just around the corner, which means it's my annual hot cross bun day (Good Friday for non-apostates) soon. I'm stocking up early on essentials. By which I mean restocking my supply of dried currants.

I'd still love to hear from you if you're enjoying this nearly a year in. And, of course, please feel free to evangelize on my behalf.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 52
Content:
Hello readers,

Welcome to the official one-year anniversary of the newsletter. Though like other grim statistics during this pandemic, I think technically the one year anniversary was a few weeks ago. Or maybe not. I took a few weeks off at Christmas, and I didn't start the newsletter until a few weeks after I had switched to the meal planning lifestyle.

The longer term future of the newsletter remains a bit uncertain. The public health situation is improving, though I'm not taking anything for granted. My misadventures in takeout during the kitchen project might not be very interesting. One idea I have had that I may follow through on is to turn this into a cookbook. It won't be the first time I've tried, but "here's what I learned doing forced meal planning during a global pandemic" might be the hook a literary agent will bite.

At any rate, if you're one of the sage, high-quality individuals who do wait with bated breath for this email every week, there's at least another month to go before anything will change. My cabinets are still an idea in the production backlog somewhere in Denmark.

Back to regularly scheduled programming.

Somehow, I hadn't realized I was down to my last tablespoon of curry powder. A very convincing katsu curry sauce was not as punchy as it could've been. For reasons beyond my understanding, I decided to do roast cauliflower with the rice, chicken, and curry sauce. Beige-on-beige-on-beige does not make for an especially appetizing photo.
The gnocchi were pretty good. I'm increasingly confident I can say I know how to make them with my head held high. The veggie ragù was close, but not quite right. The biggest problem was the lentils. They shouldn't be there at all, Jamie Oliver. It felt almost heretical to waste precious Puy lentils. Otherwise, the sauce was amazingly convincing. Swapping the lentils out for some more roughly chopped mushrooms will do the trick next time.When it came time to do the tofu, I realized that I forgot to buy tofu. Fortunately I made more gnocchi than I needed, so I'll rustle something up with those to bridge the gap. The tofu will get an airing in the week to come. Or else.
As the weather warms up and view outside gets greener, the menus need to reflect the change. It also occurred to me that I haven't done pasta in a couple of months. Even if I hadn't just done a ragù, that sauce feels too heavy for spring. Instead, I'm going to do a shellfish pasta. I have some really wonderful bronze-drawn Afeltra spaghetti that needs using. That will go with maybe a white bean salad. There's something a bit sad about pasta as a whole meal by itself.

Finally, I'm going to do an ajo blanco with fish and salad. I'd really love to get my hands on a fatty fish other than salmon — sardines or mackerel come to mind — though I suspect that won't be possible. I'd love to pair that with asparagus, assuming I can find good asparagus.

For a sweet, there's really nothing more appropriate than this Coronaversary cake from the people at Honey & Co. Yes, it's indulgent. But we've survived a year of this and I still really can't leave the house much. It's as good a time as any for a treat.

As always, I'd love to hear from you, and please feel free to share this with anyone you know!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 50
Content:
Hello readers,

It's been another week of getting less done than planned, for some good reasons and some less good reasons. On the plus side, the weather was just about warm enough to do some outdoor dining. One less dinner to do at home, in other words. The restaurant did a very made-for-Instagram tahini cheesecake. It was extremely tasty; I have mixed feelings about Instagram-worthiness driving menu decisions. On the negative side, I slightly overdid the paella and then realized that I needed a pasta machine for the ramen. So no ramen, and no photos of the bao, which aren't going to happen before my (admittedly self-imposed) filing deadline.
The paella was also slightly compromised by the unavailability of the shellfish that I like to use. I still haven't quite been able to get a good socarrat at home, though I feel like every time I inch closer. For a long time I thought it was the rice. Then I hunted down a bag of fancy heritage bomba rice from Spain, and realized it was my technique. I suspect I use slightly too much liquid or the "high" setting on my circa 1980s range isn't quite enough.
Considering next week, I'll start with the sweet. It's Easter next weekend, meaning it's time for buns. For the last few years I've pretended to be Episcopalian and made hot cross buns on Good Friday, as is the tradition. I planned on doing that this year as well until reading about Colomba di Pasqua, the Italian equivalent, in the latest Ottolenghi piece in the Guardian. Chocolate is more Christmas than Easter in my mind, but variety is always good.

I'm hoping I can get some in-season asparagus now that spring is here. I don't know that I want to do anything radically complicated with it. Maybe I'll do a velouté if I'm feeling fancy. Either way, I'll do that with salmon on Puy lentils, one of my favorite combinations.

For a veggie option, I'm going to try my hand at mushroom tacos. Paired with some kind of roast vegetable. Here again, I feel like I don't know the cultural context well enough to know what would go with something like that.

Mostly as an excuse to bake more bread, I'm going to try this take on baked eggs with za'atar. Despite obviously making very different food week to week, something is beginning to feel repetitive. Something about an egg main for dinner worked as a way to mix it up.

Once again, I'd love to hear from you if you're enjoying this, and please feel more than welcome to plug this to others!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 51
Content:
Hello readers,

Spring seems to be arriving in fits and starts. Where last weekend it was warm enough to eat outside, this weekend is decidedly more frosty. On the plus side, this has meant all my plans have gone more or less as expected. It feels about right for Easter.

Last week's promised bao turned out to be a big success. I was particularly impressed with myself considering I'd never done these more sandwich-style dumplings before. If I had to split hairs, cilantro would've been a nice addition. Once my pre-renovation moratorium on new kitchen gadgets is lifted, I'm going to finally invest in a set of bamboo steamers, which would've made these easier to make.
The mushroom tacos left something to be desired. My cooking was too gentle for starters. I also thought the tomato was too aggressive. It was kind of like eating a pasta sauce in a tortilla. Or, perhaps not quite as bad as that, but definitely not the best Mexican food I've ever had by a long way.

Speaking of Mexico, all the asparagus at my friendly neighborhood Whole Foods was from, yes, Mexico. It's not the same as the really fresh, in-season stuff, even if I feel like most of what we get in the Northeast comes from New Jersey. Not that I have anything against New Jersey per se either, except that it's not exactly a place I associate with a terroir. All of which is to say I bought spinach to go with the salmon and lentils instead.
Another surprising casualty: my Italian knockoff hot cross buns. I tried going to three different stores, and none of them had hazelnuts. My block of very fancy block of chocolate, purchased for the occasion, remains unused. But Good Friday needed to be celebrated. I've never had a problem making hot cross buns that taste good. This year's batch was superb. Many years into the HXB tradition, though, and I still haven't learned the lesson that the piping needs to be very thin and delicate to counteract the heat of the oven. Still photogenic enough to feature (just); not my best work either.The leek-egg combination lived up to expectations. It did go well with crusty bread and a glass of dry white wine.

Moving along to the week ahead, I'm going to get some preserved lemons going. They are truly magical, and I've never been able to find them at the grocery store in the US. Luckily, they're extremely easy — if slow — to make.

The overtly veggie choice for the week will be a permutation of gnocchi with a mushroom ragù. It's maddeningly difficult to find a recipe that isn't written by a questionable vegan health guru who seems more concerned about including walnuts for unspecified reasons than making a good sauce. It's a noble concept, however, so I'd like to figure it out.

I'm in an Anglo-Japanese comfort food mood. That or my travel withdrawal is so strong I'm craving airport food. Which is to say I'm going to try my hand at a katsu curry, Wagamama staple. In a sea of banality, it's the most exciting place to get lunch or dinner on a Heathrow layover. (Yes, I know I could go to an actual Wagamama here, today. Wagamama is not that exciting, though: I'm seizing my opportunity to actually cook while I still can.)

Last but not least, I'm going to try another Ottolenghi recipe in the form of black pepper tofu. I'll put the lessons from the salt and pepper fish attempt — use an uncoated pan and turn the heat up very high — to use this time. As with the Mexican food, I feel like I'm on shaky cultural ground. The few places I found anything suggested the salt-pepper-shallow fry concept is Cantonese. Given the sources, I'm still dubious. If you run a food blog and want to write about food history, citations would be helpful!

My supply of hot cross buns is plentiful, so I don't think I'm going to do another sweet this week. If I do, I'd be tempted to go back to my croissant project.

If you're enjoying the newsletter, I'm always happy to hear from people. Likewise — and I know I say it every week — please feel free to evangelize on my behalf.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 53
Content:
Hello readers,

Nigella Lawson's latest cookbook has a US publication date. Through the power of international shipping, I can vouch for it being great. It's a shame they didn't use the UK cover for the US edition. I'd highly recommend the interview she did with Helen Rosner in the New Yorker.

While I'm recommending, there's a new newsletter called Mess that promises to be good. (Warning: Not in English!) It has (much) higher production values than this and features every Sunday a new recipe from someone interesting.

From last week, I should probably be less surprised that deep fried tofu is delicious. Or that anything deep fried is delicious. Yet here we are. The hint of fire from the pepper and the chili was excellent. My only real complaint: for such a superficially simple dish, it took forever. At least in part, I suspect I wasn't aggressive enough with the heat under the oil. There's still a chance I'll be cooking with more power sometime this summer.
The pasta was more restrained. Predictable, perhaps. I don't know there's much to say other than it's a really excellent combination.
My dreams of something fishy but different were once again foiled by a combination of bad planning, laziness, and ingredient unavailability. My supposedly upmarket local grocery store (aka Whole Foods) still only has questionable asparagus from Mexico, and there were no sardines at the fish counter. Then I realized I didn't have any stale bread for the sauce. The result was a very monochrome striped bass with butter parsley sauce that wasn't very photogenic.

I usually try to do my big bake — in this case the corona-versary cake — on Friday or Saturday night. Frying the tofu and cleaning up afterwards took me out of the mood. A report on the cake will have to wait until next week.

The weather is bedding down into something spring-like, and I'm in the mood for jerk chicken. Maybe I'm getting ahead of myself and that's more a summer than spring dish. If I'm feeling extra heretical, I may turn that into taco fodder. Once again, I'd really, really love to pair that with asparagus. Once again, I fear that plan will be foiled by lack of good produce.

Returning to my stash of frozen salmon, I'm going to try this cheeky Ottolenghi recipe for salmon with pine nut salsa. The origin story is excellent, and makes me feel at least slightly better about conforming to a certain stereotype. At least the people chez Ottolenghi have some self-awareness.

For a veggie option, I'm in the mood for a curry. Perhaps something like this cauliflower curry. It always feels like a bit of a cheat to bind everything together with coconut milk, but it's undeniable that it works.

Given my late start on the very indulgent corona-versary cake from last week, I'll probably refrain from doing a sweet. Unless, of course, I spot some really good produce on my resupply trip and come up with something to do with it. Guessing, that seems unlikely.

Every week I say it, and every week I mean it: I'd love to hear from you if you're enjoying the newsletter, and please don't hesitate to forward or plug it to friends.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 54
Content:
Hello readers,

I feel as though the world is in limbo. Soon, I'll be protected against COVID-19. Yet I have to remind myself that as badly as we bungled — continue to bungle, really — the management of the pandemic, we're head and shoulders above the rest of the world in truly being able to open back up.

Which is to say, I had the realization that while I'll feel safe going about the world, the rest of it is still so closed down, there's a lot less that's safe to go and see. But who knows: perhaps there's a travel edition of the newsletter in the cards if my passport becomes usable again.

The corona-versary cake that didn't make the deadline last week was a success. Though if we're honest, it's basically a flourless chocolate cake with tahini. I couldn't bring myself to buy almond butter for one cake — they said a swap was acceptable! Perhaps my tahini obsession is a sign I've been too strongly influenced by Yotam Ottolenghi and his brigade. I'm not sure what I did to make the top so much like the surface of the moon. When it tastes good and you're not changing people $30 for a slice, I don't know how much that matters.
The jerk chicken, while delicious, falls once again into that category of food that tastes great but looks a little rough in photos. I'm always scared when I throw the habaneros (I can never find scotch bonnets) in the marinade, and every time I'm pleasantly surprised it's more a floral background warmth than something to burn the roof of my mouth off.
The cauliflower curry is the kernel of something great. The flavors were fantastic. If nothing else, I'm definitely adding rogan josh curry paste to my more permanent repertoire. Swapping the suggested boiled lemon for preserved lemon was a great idea. The sauce was a bit watery — probably because I added too much water — and it was a shame all the charred curry paste got dissolved into the sauce upon the suggested flip. The onions were a bit of a mystery, too: more charred and rubbery than sweet and melting.

Next time I'll probably use less water, give the cauliflower more time to cook on the cooktop, and then use the grill only for finishing.

The recipe made so much curry, in fact, that I still haven't had a chance to do the salmon in time for my self-imposed publishing deadline.

Speaking of next week, the foray into a veggie curry has me in a curry mood. My inclination is to something fairly straightforward like a prawn green curry. I still haven't found a truly exceptional Indian food blog that's my speed, so I slightly lack for inspiration.

To go with I'm going to try my hand at doing naan at home. Like pizza, I doubt I can achieve reference quality. But I suspect my slab of baking steel will produce something serviceable to go with the curry. It's also a great opportunity for doing a warmly spiced shallot saag.

Keeping with the increasingly spring-like weather, I'm in the mood for tacos. What exactly, I'm not sure. I'd kind of like to be virtuous and something with mushrooms. In the moment, I may cave to my hedonism and get pork shoulder.

I'm keeping my proverbial powder dry in case I need a night off to recover from dose one of the COVID-19 vaccine. If you're looking for another idea, I'll toss out this recipe from Ruth Rodgers (of one of my favorite restaurants) for roasted whole sea bass with fingerling potatoes. Extremely easy, extremely good.

For a sweet, I'm hoping inspiration strikes while I'm shopping and I come up with something fruit-based. If that doesn't happen, I continue to enjoy playing with shortbread. What struck my fancy there, I don't know. But I'm enjoying exploring the space and making it my own. I also caught wind of a restaurant in London that does kinako pain perdu, but that will have to wait for a future edition.

Last but not least, my usual appeal: I'd love to hear from you, and feel free to do some promotion on my behalf.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 55
Content:
Hello readers,

It has been an up and down week. On the up, I'm now very much a convert to mango chutney. At this stage, I'm not entirely sure what to do with it beyond the cheat's shrimp curry recipe I tried out. But it provided a really nice zing in that context. The color reminded me of a laksa. I didn't have the time or really the energy to try the naan. That will have to wait for another time.
My friendly neighborhood Whole Foods had local asparagus in stock from the pastoral idyll of New Jersey. Maybe not the best asparagus I've ever had, but easily the best I've had this year.

On the down, while my reaction to the COVID-19 injection was not awful, it really took my left arm out of commission for the next couple of days. Suffice to say the cheap and cheerful Thai restaurant down the street got some solid business from me in the last week.
My experiment in low-carbon carnitas was a serious dud. There's nothing to recommend the concept as far as I'm concerned. It looked the part, but was flavorless and not very filling, like most dishes that lead with vegan rather than flavor. Mushrooms are pretty lean to begin with, but I doubt even using lard would have compensated for their utter lack of interestingness. Not to mention it was unbelievably expensive. Part of the beauty of carnitas is taking a relatively cheap cut of pork and transforming it into something amazing. At something close to $20 a pound for king oyster mushrooms, I might as well have been making lobster tacos.

Looking ahead to next week, I recently discovered that Kenji Lopez-Alt has a YouTube channel, which led me to another YouTube channel called Chinese Cooking Demystified. Watching their discussion of fried rice made me want to experiment with that concept a bit. I'll probably start with their basic formula and see what happens from there.

My preserved lemons are finally ready to be used, and to me the quintessential preserved lemon food is a tagine with couscous. Like Mexican food, I think of dishes from the Maghreb as spring or summer food because that part of the world is pretty warm year-round. While probably heretical to someone from the region, I usually toss in carrots or another vegetable that works with a braise to make it into a one-pot situation.

Finally, assuming they have it at the fish counter, I'm in the mood for monkfish. I'll probably do it very simply by popping it in a foil pouch and cooking it in the oven. Probably with some white wine, rosemary, and a copious amount of butter. This might be another opportunity to enjoy the short window for in-season asparagus if it's still there on my next trip.

For a sweet, I'm going to take advantage of the temperate weather to have yet another run at doing croissants. Between the ongoing travel ban to Europe, my impending kitchen project, and the arrival of warmer weather, my window for great croissants this side of September is closing. I feel like I get better with every attempt, but I still haven't quite gotten to a point I'm happy with.

As usual, I'd love to hear from you and please feel free to forward to anyone you think might enjoy it!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 56
Content:
Hello readers,

My impending kitchen renovation is, well, still impending. But I did spend another $300 this week to upgrade to "white glove" delivery for the cabinets. Apparently this is cheaper than having a prospective contractor do it. It's progress of a sort.

Food-wise, my preserved lemons weren't quite as ready as I thought. Not that it detracted much from the would-be tagine, which is always a winner. Visually, I've come to the conclusion that this is one dish where purple carrots don't work as well as their more common orange cousins. It seemed fine in the pot; the photos looked a bit gross.

For once the fish counter did have what I wanted, so I got my hands on monkfish. That really is not very photogenic at all either — or at least it's not with my amateurish pouch making and opening skills — even if it's very tasty. The heady wash of crème fraîche, rosemary, and white wine is very nice with a bit of crusty bread.
My attempt at fried rice made my kitchen project feel that much more imperative. My circa 1980 GE range isn't as bad as it might appear, but nor can it pump 7,700 W into a single pan. That's still nowhere close to what a restaurant-style wok burner can do, but it's a lot closer than whatever I have now gets. It would also have been a lot easier to toss in a wok. Appliance and cookware deficiencies aside, taking the advice of Chinese Cooking Demystified did produce pretty good fried rice. I still have work to do, but it's the best fried rice I've ever made at home.

The verdict on my latest croissant attempt will have to wait. As usual, despite my best intentions I couldn't get it done before my deadline.

Moving into next week, watching Kenji Lopez-Alt's YouTube channel has put me in the mood for pizza. I'm not sure I'm ready to have pizza every Friday, but it's usually a winner. As ever, my usual recipe is this very basic one from one of my favorite pizza places. Purely for visual interest, I'm going to deviate from the norm and do a mushroom pizza rather than the usual margherita.

As an aside, Kenji's recent piece revisiting the no-knead bread phenomenon is worth a read. The video he did explaining the updated technique was really interesting.

The weather still isn't that redolent of a Spanish summer, but that's not going to stop me from doing another repeat favorite and toss together a paella. As with fried rice, I'm unlikely to make the best paella ever at home. That's not to say it can't be good. I know I mentioned the trick, such as it is, not too long ago: keep the portions small.

Mostly as an excuse for returning to my naan experiment, I'll round things out with a nice dal over rice. I'll probably whip up some cauliflower to go along with that. Doubling up with naan and rice feels a bit too decadent. I feel like cauliflower still melds well with the dal.

For a sweet, I've discovered that François-Régis Gaudry does YouTube videos as well. (He's the host of a food show called On va déguster on France Inter, the approximate French equivalent of NPR or Radio 4.) In particular, the recipe for a flan pâtissier that he featured from pastry wünderkind Christophe Michalak caught my eye. It's a bit of a cheat by using corn starch as a stabilizer, but it looks really tasty.

As I say every week, it's always fun to hear from you, and please feel free to forward this to anyone else who might enjoy.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 57
Content:
Hello readers,

While my kitchen project (and thus to some extent this newsletter) remain in timeline limbo, there is some progress. The cabinets have left the factory in Denmark. Such are the conditions around global cargo, however, that the delivery date could be anything between the beginning of June through the end of July.

In actual food last week, the croissants were, sadly, not my best. Granted, it's difficult to fail so miserably making croissants that they're not worth eating. I've concluded the big problem is speed. The butter and dough warm at different rates: the dough is mostly water (specific heat of 4 J/g°K), whereas the butter is mostly fat (specific heat of 2 J/g°K). Not working fast enough, the butter heats more quickly and bleeds through, causing problems. If I had to guess, it's more a question of relaxing the dough more effectively than my lack of upper-body strength.
My paella was a lot more successful. After watching a few more videos, I realized that I wasn't being aggressive enough with the heat. I finally got the nice dry, separate grains that are the hallmark of great paella. Though this made me realize maybe I should get a carbon steel pan: I couldn't scrape the socarrat off the bottom. But my pre-renovation new purchase moratorium stands. More to put in storage whenever the project kicks off.The curry was very nice. It's hard to go wrong with ginger and cilantro. The naan were a bit more of a mixed bag. As usual, it comes down to something technical that I can't really change. My baking steel is great, but it's not enough to overcome the fact my oven can't get above 550 °F. Tasty, yes. Not quite as nice as bread out of a real tandoor.
It was frankly nice to switch up the pizza. After discovering Kenji Lopez-Alt's YouTube channel, I'm now very jealous he has an outdoor space to set up a pizza oven.
As usual, something failed due to bad planning. In this case, I ran out of milk and completely forgot to buy cream. No flan this week: flan next week.

Spring has quickly transitioned into full-on summer. Spring and fall never feel like the last quite as long as they should. Maybe it's premature: I'm moving into full-on summer food mode.

Starting with the conspicuously veggie option, I'm going to have a run at doing tacos with fried tofu. I couldn't find a recipe that got everything I wanted. Most people making tacos with tofu do not share the yen for decadence I crave. My current plan is to use the cornflour technique from the black pepper tofu from a few weeks ago. More ambitiously, I'm going to try making my own corn tortillas if I can find masa on my next shop.

Next, it's back to another favorite: the always great moules marinières. I'm not sure there's much more to say, other than that I'll eat them with a light salad and great bread.

Last but not least, I'm going to do gambas al ajillo, a fairly straightforward garlic shrimp dish. It would probably be heretical in Spain, but I really like the idea of serving that with coarse polenta to soak up all that garlic oil. With all semblance of cultural coherence out the window, I really want to try this carrot salad. (Can you tell I still have a ton of time to watch cooking videos on YouTube?)

It still feels too early in the year to find good stone fruit. If I see some great strawberries I may pick some up and do a sweet with those. Otherwise, I'll remember to buy milk and cream, and return to the flan pâtissier that I had planned to make last week.

It's always great to hear from you. After a number of people independently suggested it, I will be making banh mi at some point soon. And of course, it is nice to know there are people who read this while I'm still mostly stuck at home. Please forward to anyone who might be interested!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 58
Content:
Hello readers,

Tomorrow I'm set to get my second dose of an amazing mRNA COVID-19 vaccine. The future of this newsletter remains a bit uncertain, though I'm beginning to do something about a few of my ideas.

In the meantime, back to the week that's been.

My attempt at making a cheap and cheerful flan pâtissier was a mixed bag. The flavor was really not bad. The texture needed work. For whatever reason I hadn't put together that this was not really an exceptional flan recipe: it's crème anglaise that's baked in the oven. And yet somehow I managed to overcook the mix, and the eggs curdled more than would've been ideal.

The Spanish-style shrimp were lusciously garlicky. Infusing the oil with the shrimp shells and garlic before adding even more slivers of garlic delivers an excellent one-two punch. However heretical, it was great with polenta.
My taco experiment was more uneven. Making scratch tortillas really is worth the time. They're so, so much better than anything I can find at the local Whole Foods. Not to mention, a huge four-pound bag of masa — enough to make many dozens of tortillas — costs less than one bag of the fancy premium tortillas from the refrigerator case. The tortilla technique could use refinement, though. They were a bit ragged and uneven despite weighing each one out.

Yet again, I'm probably more surprised than I should be that fried tofu is delicious. My ad hoc salsa was held back by mediocre tomatoes and my own injudicious addition of citrus.
Bad planning struck again with the mussels; I'll carry those forward to the week ahead.

Speaking of, summer has well and truly arrived. I had to turn on the air conditioning for the first time this year earlier in the week.

It was in last week's Guardian, so I assume it's in-season: for this week's veggie option I'm going to try this recipe for tofu in a sambal from the excellent Ottolenghi column. I'll stir fry some baby bok choy to go along with that.

The moules marinières have to make their return. I'll either make some bread or do the unthinkable and buy frozen fries. Even last week's shallow frying, while delicious, was too much cleanup. With that I'm in the mood for maybe a cucumber salad. It's not very culturally coherent I'll admit, but I find more prototypical salads boring.

Finally, it's back to my never-ending supply of frozen fish. Restaurants in France were allowed to begin re-opening last week, so there's been an explosion of ideas from the people and places I follow. One had the idea of doing salmon with a sort of Indian twist using tandoor spices. I'm going to give it a try and see what happens.

For a sweet we once again begin the vexed question of when to have my annual run at replicating the best peach tart I've ever eaten. My hunch is that it's still too early in the year, and I need to wait for high summer. Still, with the weather as it is, I'm inclined to a more summery sweet. Perhaps a clafoutis. I have a difficult time going to the trouble of making a full-on tart when the fruit isn't excellent.

It's always great to hear from you and as always a plug to share this with anyone else who might enjoy. My new cabinets could arrive as early as this week, though there's still no firm plan for the work to begin. In other words, there will be a next week.

Until then,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 59
Content:
Hello readers,

Back in the spring of 2020, one of the talking heads I listen to said that it would be harder to unlock than to shut everything down. Here in the closest polity the US has to Finland, most remaining restrictions were lifted this weekend. Something has changed, and yet it's still not quite right. Despite the carnage, there are many changes I'm going to embrace wholeheartedly. Once you start ordering lunch ahead for pickup, you'll never go back to endlessly waiting around. In other ways, I'm having to confront other shifts as I reorient.

Which is a roundabout way of saying that the time is steadily approaching to wind down this newsletter. It's been fun, and it will keep going for a few more weeks as I try to figure out what life in a post-vaccine world looks like. Or at the outside whenever my kitchen renovation finally gets going.

Do not despair, however: I have another project in the works to fill the void for the small group of you who are still following along with this project. Watch this space.

The last week really brings home the strange place I'm in. To start, while I clearly was aware that I'd get my second dose of the vaccine last week, I completely failed to register that having the second dose would take me out of commission for a couple of days. Still no mussels, then.

Likewise, as other people I know are getting vaccinated as well, I'm having to readjust to occasionally not cooking at home, as was the case this last week. No salmon, then.

The absence of a clafoutis is something I can try to blame on Whole Foods, and by extension my moral nemesis Jeff Bezos: they didn't have any produce that looked worth the bother.
Fortunately for this newsletter, I did have time to make the tofu sambal, which I'd recommend. If I were to do it again, I might pare back the quantity of maple syrup and find an alternative to deep frying the tofu.

Looking ahead to next week, I really, truly, will make the mussels. My continued misses haven't been for want of trying. Unlike a lot of other dishes — where you certainly don't have concerns if, say, tofu sits in the refrigerator for a few extra days — mussels demand to be cooked close to their purchase date. But the weather looks warm and my schedule looks free, so I ought to be able to make it happen.

My giant bag of masa isn't going anywhere, either. I love the idea of doing a carnitas; I don't love the idea of braising pork shoulder for hours and hours when it's really hot and humid outside. Instead, I'll do a bit of a cheat and do tacos with chorizo. I thought about trying tamales, too, which really do demand masa. Maybe another time.

As a veggie option for the week, I'm going to return my hand to the veggie ragù concept. It's really the antithesis of what I should be doing at this time of year. On the other hand, a more seasonal pasta dish almost inevitably involves tomatoes (still not quite in season here) or seafood (not veggie).

For a sweet, I'm thinking of splitting the difference and doing some kind of pavlova. Nothing too over-the-top or fancy. Reduced to its core, a pavlova is nothing more than a bit of meringue, whipped cream, and fruit. Now that the door is theoretically open to me having people round, whether or not the social pandemic of flakiness ever makes that happen, the idea of doing elaborate sweets for one feels somehow different.

As ever, it's great to hear from the occasional person who drops me a line. Stay tuned for what comes next!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 60
Content:
Hello readers,

Today is the last day that I'm not fully vaccinated according to the CDC. Though it's taking a bit longer for the world around me to completely roar back to life. The newsletter is reaching its end, but we're not quite there yet.

If you're worried, I can share the follow on to this. I've very creatively called the new project a recipe log (should that be Recipe Log?), which, amazingly enough was an available domain name. Once this newsletter comes to an end, I'll share details on how to subscribe to an email drip. It's more or less moving my handwritten paper notes into the 21st century.

Looking back on the week that's been, I did indeed make the mussels. I did not succeed in taking a photo that was in focus. They're great. I don't know what more there is to say.
The chorizo tacos were surprisingly good. Though on another level this reminds me of the fried tofu. I probably shouldn't be surprised that a taco filling made with fatty, salty Mexican chorizo would be pretty tasty. I am quickly realizing that if I even semi-regularly make my own corn tortillas, I should probably buy a piece of equipment to make forming the tortillas speedier. This should've been a simple dinner; making almost-scratch tortillas does vastly complicate the job.
My second run at an eco-conscious ragù was better, but still not quite where I'd like it to be. It reminded me of the mushroom carnitas knockoff: not rich enough, a little flat. There was a part of me that wanted to add some lardons or pancetta, which would obviously defeat the purpose.

Moving into next week, I'm going to make more tacos, my lack of specialized equipment notwithstanding. First, however, a point of frustration. I grew up eating what I now think of as "tacos." That is: fluorescent orange cheddar cheese, ground beef seasoned with a packet of seasoning, taco shells out of a box. Later, I discovered a higher grade of taco, and it's that taco I'm exploring.

Doing a search for, say, "taco recipes" on Google is deeply frustrating. One of the hits on the first page of results: "Just Like Taco Bell Tacos." I hasten to add that in Mexico Taco Bell is marketed as American food. Not a single hit from a source that looked even vaguely Mexican.

My frustration aside, I eventually remembered that Rick Bayless has a website, and found this interesting idea for roasted cauliflower tacos. A veggie option, and a high-quality taco concept. There's even a video walkthrough.

One realization that I've had over the last 15 months: much as I love shopping for food, Whole Foods is not as seasonal a market as they claim. There isn't really much of a point in going more than once a week, even when that's allowed by public health advice. Hence: I still have a giant supply of frozen fish. For my easy out of the week, I'm going to do the excellent miso salmon that I discovered early in the first lockdown.

Finally, if I wind up needing a third option, I feel like I'm in a groove with my paella technique. I also have a ton of frozen scallops I need to use.

None of this quite corresponds with the weather we're having. But I've resigned myself to the fact that, without a large outdoor patio to have one of those wonderfully relaxed very late dinners in the dying summer heat, even modest air conditioning doesn't really gel with gazpacho.

For a sweet, I've more or less given up on there being great local fruit dessert fodder this early in the season. But I almost don't care. I'm going to do a peach galette, even if the peaches have come from California.

There are still a few more weeks of this to go, so stay tuned!

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 61
Content:
Hello readers,

I've set a date: the last edition of the 2020-21 coronavirus pandemic newsletter will go out on the 27th of June. It's been fun, helped keep me grounded during a complicated year, and been useful for forcing me to try new ideas. I'll have more to say in the final edition.

By next week I'm hoping to have the newsletter drip of recipes from my quasi-blog ready for sign ups as well.

The last week especially has confirmed my feeling it's time to draw this to a close. Almost overnight my world has switched from being stuck at home to people once again being so flaky it's difficult to schedule anything.

Through the vagaries of time management, several would-be dinners tuned out to be not-dinners, which left me slightly caught out. I made the tacos, and the paella, and the fish, and then realized all I didn't have enough food to make a complete meal by yesterday.
Even so, the cauliflower tacos were definitely a success. I don't know whether it was the tortillas or the crème fraîche, but these were satisfying and interesting veggie tacos that I would make again.

I'm also now very confident in my paella making skills. The trick really is going small. My widest pan isn't big enough to do paella for more than about one hungry person. I don't totally understand why a shallower distribution of rice makes such a big difference yet. Fortunately, now that I have the process down, I can see how it would be possible to make paella à la minute in a restaurant.
The miso salmon is the miso salmon. It's a great combination and that's all there is to say about it.

Looking to the week ahead, I'm going to reaffirm my belief in planning for the worst and hoping for the best. By which I mean I'm going to plan for seven full meals, and carry a few over rather than being shorthanded. Getting cheap and cheerful takeout should be a choice, not a necessity.

My bag of masa remains pretty full, so I'm going to continue my exploration of the taco concept. I've given up on trying to find a good source of taco recipes, though. I'll keep this my veggie option for the week with something like a black bean-poblano filling. If you're looking for a good salsa recipe, Kenji Lopez-Alt's YouTube channel has a video walkthrough of something very close to my method.

Next: I'm going to keep my promise and do some banh mi. I'm tempted to try this lemongrass-tofu variation. Not because I'm per se opposed to, say, pork belly, but rather because I don't want to have to deal with the mess of, say, shallow frying breaded pork belly.

Finally, I'm in the mood for jerk chicken. If i'm feeling ambitious, I may try to hunt down some scotch bonnet chilis to see what impact that has. The marinade and grill does a lot to moderate the intensity of the chilis — plus the recipe doesn't use many — but I find having that lick of heat and fruitiness makes a big difference.

Now it's well and truly summer, I have a difficult time doing big, rich desserts. Taking inspiration from the banh mi, I've plucked out a recipe for tapioca and coconut sorbet from The Slanted Door. Apparently this is more of a Taiwanese dessert in the vein of bubble tea. I'm not a huge fan of bubble tea, but I do like tapioca more generally, so this feels worth trying.

As ever, it's always great to hear from you. Stayed tuned for what comes next.

Until next week,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, Week 62
Content:
Hello readers,

As promised, you can now sign up for my new newsletter. Forgive the lackluster production values: I'm not trying to turn this into a business or become a so-called influencer. I'm hoping instead to send a message approximately once a month with highlights, observations, and tidbits. I'll also continue adding and updating recipes from my paper notebooks in my Git repository and that's published in a more readable format. I'll mention this next week as well — the last edition of this particular experiment.

I did get up to a fair bit of cooking this past week. In fact, I got through everything, with the usual dose of planning-related errors and unavailability of ingredients that I'll continue to blame on Jeff Bezos.

Starting with the sweet, I wound up having to eat coconut sorbet without the tapioca. My local Whole Foods had tapioca powder but no tapioca pearls. A blob of amorphous tapioca goo was not appealing. But I did get my hands on some pretty good coconut sorbet, so it wasn't a complete disaster.
The banh mi were a bit more mixed. My sourdough starter, going strong since before the pandemic set in, got infected by something orange and spotty. It was pretty gross and a little sad to have to reboot my starter. It also meant my baguettes for the banh mi weren't quite as good as they could've been. Bread sur levain really is a lot tastier. But it was, overall, a pretty nice experiment on a hot, muggy day.
My black bean tacos were also a success. I'm getting very good at making tortillas. More excitingly, I realized they had tomatillos (albeit, canned) at my local Whole Foods, so I made some vibrant green salsa verde.
I did not succeed in finding (read: did not put in the effort to find) scotch bonnet chilis, however. Though the jerk chicken still has a nice floral kick from the habaneros that I did get my hands on.

Looking to the week ahead, I'm going to start with, yes, another Ottolenghi recipe from the most recent Guardian column. Like Nigella Lawson, I'm a huge fan of the anchovy. Pairing it with charred aubergine sounds like a great idea.

More in-season, I'm going to do a pasta with mussels or, if you have friends you want to impress, linguine alle cozze. I had dreams of making this outdoors on Lake Annecy, but alas I wasn't willing to take the risk proving I'm vaccinated to the French border police. With that I'll do some sort of chunky salad. Maybe something as simple as last-of-the-season asparagus with a vinaigrette.

Keeping with the summery feel, despite not having an outdoor cooking space, I'm in the mood for something burger-y. I'm thinking of something like these chickpea-mushroom burgers, since, technically, the eggplant is not veggie. I made way too much Vietnamese-style pickled carrots; they might make a good topping. With that, probably some sweet potato fries.

I'm keeping my hopes up the first of the overpriced but delicious summer berries will make their appearance when I go shopping this week. Barring that, it's back to a meringue to use up my carton of egg whites.

I'm getting melancholic! This has been a fun part of the last year and change. Again, I'll say more next week in the final issue. As a reminder, if you'd like to keep hearing from me in a similar format, sign up for the new newsletter.

Until next week, for the last time,
Joseph

Subject: Confinement Cooking, The End
Content:
Hello readers,

This is the last one! It's been fun, but it's also time. Putting this together every week is a surprisingly big challenge. I don't want to flake out when, as is increasingly happening, I actually have plans and something to do on weekends.
But that's not to say the adventure is over. If you haven't already, please sign up for my new newsletter! I'm planning to send something out once a month with musings and observations in the same vein as this. Without compromising my security posture, the first edition should have some content that hasn't been possible for the last year and change. Not to mention, at some point my kitchen renovation will happen, and I'm sure that will be quite a journey. It's been so long, I may actually be able to follow through on my original plan and invite myself to people's homes to cook while I'm living on a construction site.
That will feed off my latest foray into online publishing, continuing my inadvertent path to mastering online marketing tools. If you've ever wondered what I actually made when I referenced something in this newsletter, my recipe log has it. Or at least it increasingly does as I slowly migrate more from paper into my Git repository.

Before a last week-in-food inventory, a quick pandemic-in-food inventory in this last edition. Three to be precise. It's been a difficult year, but as usual a major perturbation also forces us to find places we hadn't thought to change.

First, having to write something every week — and thus live up to people's expectations — really helped push me out of ruts. Having to dig deep and try new recipes has been really useful. I'd never have tried making a biryani or some of the more exotic Ottolenghi dishes without "needing" to for these purposes. Fortunately, having realized it's actually not that much work to expand my repertoire, I'm hoping it won't take exposing my food habits to the world to push me to be a little more adventurous.

Second, it's nice not to go shopping for food multiple times a week. I'm not sure I'll be quite as fastidious as I was when it was a public health necessity. Even so, it's a nice convenience, only made possible with a bit more planning than I did pre-pandemic. Meal planning is here to stay.

Third, ordering ahead online is great. Even before the pandemic, I would force myself to go out and buy something for lunch if I was working from home. But until it was a necessity, I thought there was something too impersonal and clunky about ordering ahead for pickup. Now, I'm a convert. It's so nice to walk in and have food prepared with your name on it, as if by magic. No waiting around. No misspelled names. Granted, I do find the process clunky. Only my three favorites have made the cut.

Not a great year, to say the least. But having an outlet to channel at least some of my nervous creativity has been nice. I'm sure there will be more lessons we learn from this experience.

Last but not least, a few notes from this last week in food.
Miraculously, they had bewitchingly fragrant local strawberries for the first time of the season. Were they overpriced? Yes. Were they delicious? Very.
I had a few leftover scallops in the freezer, so I dressed up the pasta for an extra deluxe finish. I also took the trick from the garlicky shrimp of a few weeks ago to boost the garlic and chili flavor. I finally got the heat level just right: enough it adds a nice kick, not so much it was painful.The Ottolenghi eggplant was disappointing, possibly more due to my incompetence than anything about the recipe. Namely, I didn't realize my tub of yoghurt was way out of date (not typical and not edible), and that I had run out of anchovies, the real tragedy.
The burgers were more unremarkable and much less photogenic. Suffice to say I undercooked the chickpeas slightly and the "burgers" weren't quite as well-bound as I would have hoped. Room to improve, I'd say.

And that's it! I may send out another reminder to sign up for the new newsletter in a few weeks, depending on numbers. Otherwise, stayed tuned there for what comes next. I'm hoping to have something to say by the middle of July.

Thanks for reading,
Joseph

Subject: One Last Time
Content:
Hello again,

I know the last edition of this was supposed to be the last-last. I also know that it often takes more than one reminder for people to take action. One last reminder, then: if you'd like to keep getting something from me in your inbox every once in a while — I'm aiming for once a month — you should subscribe to my new newsletter!

It's been surprising how many people were disappointed not to be getting an email from me every week. From my perspective, I hit a button on my computer every Sunday and then took it on faith that people saw and maybe enjoyed what I wrote.

For the try-before-you-buy crowd, I published the first edition a few weeks ago. The format is still evolving. I'm trying to keep a similar format to this, but with a looser deadline and longer timescale now that I actually leave the house.

Otherwise, this really is it. It's been a fun pandemic project.

Thanks again for reading,
Joseph
